DO NOT WRITE BELOW THIS LINE
April 13, 1957

Here is an inquiry which has at last reached me.

He may be intending to make teaching a career, but his letter doesn't say so, and I am unable to supply any information about him.

C.A.C.
Dear sir,

I wrote you last year about teaching for the summer months relieving a teacher in an Indian Residential School. As it happened my letter arrived just too late and I missed the chance to accompany a friend of mine, Harold Speers to Messinesse.

I have Interim First Class Certificate number 27289. This past year I have been a student at the University of Toronto and I expect to go into a course in Honours Geography and Economics next term. My examinations were completed on May 11 and I am free until the fall term commences late in September. I have taught at Missanabie, White River, and Campbellville, Ontario, all big schools (White River was graded, the others ungraded) for nearly four years, my last inspector being L.L. Skuce of Milton, Ontario. I am able to assume a principal's position if desired, and like to do special art, and craft work although I have no special certificates. I have also taught music and theory.

I am a young man of twenty six years, six feet three inches in height, of Scotch ancestry; neither smoke nor drink, and have experience in the north, and with Indian children, whom I liked very much. I am prepared to go wherever I am needed.

If you are relieving teachers in any of the residential schools perhaps you will write me as soon as possible. I would be glad to send further information as desired. I enjoy teaching and would welcome a chance to teach this summer, beginning at once or etc. I am enclosing a picture so that you may have an idea with whom you are dealing.

Yours truly,

George W. Michie

May 15, 1951.

To Rev. R. J. Renison, M.A., D.D.,
Bishopspoke,
Porcupine Highway, Schumacher, Ont.

My lord,

A young man is graduating from the Stratford Normal School this year and is interested in teaching among the Indians at a Northern Ontario mission for the summer months if there is sufficient remuneration for the work.

He tells me he has not as yet secured a job in southern Ontario for the summer months and would be very willing to teach in Northern Ontario for the summer months until he takes a school here in Southern Ontario in September.

He has volunteered for this summer work as a result of a talk to Anglican Normal School students by Mrs. A. C. Williams of Rupert's House, which I arranged for her.

Will you kindly reply immediately, my lord, in this matter. The matter of remuneration is of specific importance, of course, and if it is acceptable, this lad is willing to rough it anywhere in the North for the summer. He is Anglican.

If you wish to write to him direct, his address is as follows:

Mr. James Miller,
Re. 4, Stratford, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

R. A. E. Ruch

Mr. Bernard Neary,
Dept. of Immigration,
Indian Affairs Branch.

Dear Sir,

In the Fernie Free Press of May 10, I read that some teachers keep their schools opened the summer in order to educate the Eskimo children who during the winter were migrating for food and thus could not profit from the use of a permanent school site.

May I enquire whether you are in need of teachers to teach the Indians or Eskimos, say during the months of July, August and September? I am willing to teach during these summer months as I plan to return to the University of Manitoba early in October. You have my letter and form of application in your files regarding teaching at Fort Resolution and Fort Franklin last July.

References can be obtained from Mr. M. Duncan, principal of the above school. I have now a B.A. and diploma in Education; i.e., an interim Collegiate Certificate.

I would prefer a Catholic community if there is a choice in the number of summer schools available, perhaps for a spot where a winter term teacher could not have been secured. I've been accustomed to teaching in isolated settlements in Northern Manitoba where I had to learn to "batch".

Yours sincerely,

L. E. Schmidt
(High School Teacher)
ESKIMO SCHOOLROOM

The teacher who chooses an Eskimo schoolroom is apt to face problems that are unique. Solutions have to be just as original.

Eskimo hunters and their families follow the caribou; spend much of the year on the move, and they prefer to travel as a family rather than to leave their children behind at the settlement to go to school. This means that school hours in the Arctic frequently have to adjust to the migratory habits of the caribou.

Last winter one teacher in Eskimo country had only a small class all season. Then in June, as holidays drew near, additional children began arriving from the south. Just as school was about to close for the season the newcomers decided they wanted it to stay open. After a busy winter on the trail learning to hunt, fish and help harness up the family dog team, the Eskimo youngsters were ready to learn to read and write. So the teacher kept school going all summer.

June 14, 1951.

Miss Shirley M. Elliott,
3 Kingsdale Avenue,
Willowdale, Ontario.

My dear Miss Elliott:

Your letter of June 10 concerns a subject on which action is usually taken much earlier in the year, and I regret that it is not now possible to offer you the employment that you have in mind.

The usual duration of such seasonal engagements is greater than the number of weeks you have available. The teachers have to pay their own transportation to points at a considerable distance and the jobs usually last from early in June to late August. The circumstances of employment and living conditions usually require male appointees, and these are usually theological college students who have a long vacation and who wish an apprenticeship in teaching and missionary work. Other appointees look forward to a career in Indian education. You indicate that you have a settled profession, and are not likely to be able to accept engagements in consecutive years. I think you will agree that for the reasons I have given it would not be mutually profitable to consider such employment this year.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Ottawa, June 21, 1951.
June 21, 1951.

Right Rev. J. Lofthouse, D.D.,
Bishop, Diocese of Keewatin,
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Bishop Lofthouse,

This will confirm our approval of the appointment of James Craig as seasonal teacher at the Lac Seul Indian Seasonal school for the summer of 1951.

Please find attached application for employment form, Reporting on Seasonal School Opening and Closing dates forms and T.D.I Income Tax forms, in duplicate.

The application form and the income tax forms should be completed and returned to us immediately. Please explain to Mr. Craig that Letter I of the reporting on Seasonal School Opening and Closing dates form must be submitted to us before he is sent his first salary cheque. Letter II must be received before his final salary cheque is issued.

He will be paid at the rate of $165.00 a teaching month. The Department does not pay travelling expenses.

The Department appreciates your nominating this teacher to fill the vacancy at Lac Seul.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Superintendent of Education

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I must apologize to you for not answering several letters which you have sent to me recently about our Indian School on James Bay.

I have been travelling a good deal and I am taking time since my return home to communicate with the Rt. Rev. Neville Clarke, my Suffragan Bishop, who lives at Moose Factory and he is in touch, not only with the various missionaries on the Bay but also with Mr. Allan, your Superintendent for that district.

I will take the stations which you mention in your letter of February 22nd, in that order:

1. Albany. The Rev. Cyril Elliott has been in charge there for the last four years. I believe that he is a very faithful, and competent teacher, who is willing to teach both morning and afternoon. He was away for nearly three months last fall, in Ireland, and returned on Jan 1st. His work was carried on by John Wesley, who is a competent teacher for the junior classes. He is the son of a clergyman.

2. East Main. The teacher there is our missionary, the Rev. George Neilson, M.A., a graduate of the University of Nova Scotia. I understand that he is very satisfactory.

3. Old Factory River. The teacher now is the Rev. Samuel Iseroff, an old fashioned Scottish Indian, who has the reputation with the inspectors of being the best Indian teacher on James Bay. You will remember that the Rev. Redfern Louttit was in charge of this mission for several years. I will refer to him again at Lansdowne House.

4. Rupert's House, is in some respects the most important Indian settlement on James Bay. The Rev. Albert Williams and his wife have been there for nearly three years. He is a veteran of the first war. His wife is a competent nurse, but I do not think that he is happy in his present post. I intend to move him as soon as possible in the spring and bring him out to civilization. I have made inquiries about your statement that there are no records since July. I know he was away for six weeks but I understand that a substitute took his place. At any rate there will be a change there shortly.

5. Lansdowne House. This post is the largest to be found in the head waters of the Albany River, three hundred miles inland from James Bay. I particularly wanted to send Mr. Louttit there because this place is growing and will be the center of that whole district. Unfortunately Mr. Louttit arrived late last fall. Mr. Bolyea, a university student from New Brunswick, who has taught for us for the last four years had a crowded school all last summer. The reason for Mr. Louttit's delay was the fact that he had a serious accident to his hand and almost lost his thumb while chopping wood. He is now all right but the Indians did not know that he was coming and therefore several families who were to be left there for the winter, went off to the bush.
I just wanted to report to you that Mr. Louittit, who is a college graduate and speaks Indian perfectly has been travelling by air throughout the whole district and I have just heard that he is moving for the winter to Fort Hope, where he is teaching school every day. If we make allowance for the fact that this place is over 100 miles from civilization I think that he did the right thing to carry out the spirit of his appointment, although he should have asked permission first. But my plan is that he will go back to Lansdowne in the spring and develop a permanent school there. He is very influential with the Indians, who like someone who can talk to them in their own language.

I am going to write to you tomorrow about the summer schools. I have a complete list of them and I have volunteers for more places than I may be able to fill. A great number of University students all over the country have heard of what the Government is doing for Indian Education and it may be that I will be able to offer you some volunteers that I am not able to place myself.

You will remember that I wrote to you some time ago about the possibility of having a permanent school at Mistassini and perhaps Waswanipi but, on second thought, it occurs to me that it might be wise to send summer teachers to those two places for this year and we will have a better opportunity of sizing up the situation before the winter.

Yours faithfully,

(Signed) Robert Renison,
Bishop of Moosonee

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I ended my last letter to you nearly a week ago with my requests with regard to the permanent Indian schools, and I stated that I would take up the matter of the Summer Schools the next morning. Unfortunately, I have been laid up for a week and I hope that my delay has not disturbed you.

The following is my list of summer schools, which I hope will be available for 1952.

1. Mistassini - I know that you are familiar with this very important district. There are probably six or seven hundred Indians in the Mistassini Band. For several years we have been fortunate enough to be able to appoint two teachers for this school. A man and his wife is the ideal arrangement, because at least one half of the children are girls, and for obvious reasons, it would not be possible to send a man and a woman who were unmarried, to take charge of the work. I propose to recommend two university graduates for this school and I would like to add an interpreter, who is available and would be exceedingly useful, and might be obtained for a very modest salary.

2. Naswanipi - is also a large mission. There are between three and four hundred Indians there. I have two university graduates available, and in this place also, I would suggest an interpreter who has acted in that capacity before.
BISHOP OF MOOSONEE
RT. REV. R. J. RENISON M.A. D.D.

3. Namiska - This is a comparatively small post, with about 100 population. We have had a school there for several years and we are building a day school this year. It is about halfway between Rupert's House on James Bay and Waswanipi. The school is very deeply appreciated by the Indians. I have a man ready to go.

4. Fort Hope - In the upper Albany River - three hundred miles inland from Albany. It is an old post and it is growing. I have a man for this place.

5. Ogoki - I have written to you about this place before. It is true that we have never had a teacher there but the Indians are entitled to that privilege. The majority of the people there are members of our church and I am very anxious to put a man there this summer because our people have wondered why they have been overlooked. I have a man available for this post.

6. Osnaburgh - This is one of our important places where we have had a teacher every year. It is not far from Pickle Crow. I believe that the Government are building a school this year. I have a teacher available who was there last year.

7. Central Patricia & Pickle Lake - This is a mining District which has grown rapidly in the last few years but Central Patricia Mine is closing down which will mean that the Indians will be pouring in here in greater numbers than ever before. I have available a very fine student from the University of Western Ontario, who has spent two years there in the past. It may be necessary for the teacher to have two schools - one at each end of the settlement. He could teach morning and afternoon if necessary - dividing his classes.

8. Collins - Last year Mr. Thomas Masson was in charge of the school at Collins. I am not quite
BISHOP OF MOOSONEE
RT. REV. R. J. RENISON M.A., D.D.

certain how it originated. It is on the railroad station west of Nakina. The Indians somehow or other have drifted down to this point from Fort Hope and Lansdowne. They speak Ojibway and it seems to be a permanent place now. I have a man who has volunteered to spend the summer there.

9. Hornpayne - is on the southern branch of the Canadian National Railroad. In the last few years it has become an important center for the Indians. Mr. Robert Ross was there last year and had a school of 50 children. The Church of England has provided a hall, with desks and furniture. We need a man there this summer.

10. Pagwa - This is a small settlement on the English river, about 50 miles west of Calstock. The Government has been trying vainly to persuade the Indians there to move up to Calstock. Eventually they may do this, but, in the meantime, during the summer, there is no provision for teachers at this point, and the children have had no opportunity of attending school. I would very much like, after speaking to Mr. Vallis, who is the head of the Calstock School, to make an experiment by opening a school for the Indian Children at Pagwa River during the summer months. I think it is worth consideration.

11. Moose Factory Day School - During the last few years the Department has sent down one or two teachers to Moose Factory for service during the summer months. Of course the regular school term is ended during that period but nevertheless, there are always a number of transient families who come to Moose Factory from the Interior during the summer months. There is a day school available and if one or two teachers were sent down there it would be an experience for them and a help to deal with an unavoidable condition which changes from year to year.
I would like to receive your instructions with regard to dealing with the volunteers whose names and whose qualifications have been submitted to me. Obviously you would like to know the qualifications of each teacher who has volunteered. I have informed them all that they can only be appointed by your Department and I would be very glad if you would let me know what action to take now. I am very anxious to notify the men but, before writing to them, I wanted to have your instructions.

I venture to enclose a form which I sent last year to each of the teachers for their information and action, and I now await your instructions before writing to them.

Yours faithfully,

Robert Moosonee

Dear Bishop Renison,

Replying to your letter of January 3rd regarding employment of Louise at the local Indian school this coming summer.

My daughter Louise is now in 10th grade high school with another year to go. She was sixteen years of age last November. She has been doing very well at school. Her marks are usually between 78 and 85%. I am sure that she would be able to handle the young children and also render service as an interpreter.

The Rev. Matthew Shecapio is in good health and getting on fine. He has been receiving his monthly stipend regularly. He now receives an old age pension of $40.00. The agent is now sending him his family allowance cheque each month instead of holding them for the summer. The monthly ration he was getting has now been cancelled because of the monthly old age pension.

All is well at Mistassini. I shall soon be starting my spring buying trips and will call the Indians.

I hope I shall something favourable from you regarding Louise. We would like her to have some useful work during her summer holidays. Kindest regards from us all.

Yours sincerely,

W. Jefferys

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Miss Grace L. Hagglund and Miss J. Horeen McConnell, presently teaching in the intermediate and primary rooms, respectively, of the Ashern school, have asked me for reports which you require in connection with applications for positions in your schools.

We do not customarily provide our teachers with reports in this province but prefer to send them direct to those concerned.

Both of the above-named teachers have done good work in their respective classrooms and I believe that both should have little difficulty in adapting themselves to the conditions found in Indian Schools, even in the far north.

Miss Hagglund, with 3rd year University standing, possesses an excellent background. She uses modern teaching techniques, conducts discussions ably, and maintains a satisfactory degree of discipline. She is resourceful and possesses the degree of confidence needed to succeed with children. Despite the fact that she has no professional training, she is rather successful in all phases of classroom management.

Miss McConnell, although a little reserved, is a conscientious and capable teacher. During the course of the year she has had considerable success in discovering the needs and abilities of her pupils and teaching them accordingly. The work done by her pupils in both Grades I and II compares favourably with any in the Division that I inspect. She is a student teacher teaching her first year. She has 2nd yr. University standing but no professional training.

Yours truly,

Inspector of Schools
March 27, 1952.

P.N.L. Phelan, Esq.,
Superintendent,
Education Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Are you likely to be able to use any of our students in Indian summer schools this next summer? I believe that Dunning and his wife have been at Pekangekum for two summers, are available. I suggested that Dunning write direct to you and he may have done so. Miss Presant, who was at Moosonee last summer, is also likely to be available. Two of our other students are also very anxious to be considered. One is a girl, Miss Joan Wickware, a class-mate of Miss Presant's. It is only fair to say that she is not as competent a person as Miss Presant, but she is a steady, reliable, common sense youngster, who would do a worthwhile job. The other student is a boy, Mr. L.A. Lundy. Lundy is a third year honour student, likewise a class-mate of Miss Presant's and Miss Wickware's. Lundy is a very sincere young man who can be relied on to do whatever he is told in a reliable way. He is younger than some students and has not shown a great deal of drive or initiative. In other words, he is the type of man who would do a methodical and honest piece of work without getting into trouble. I am not sufficiently familiar with the young men whom you normally draw on for these summer schools, but I think that Lundy would measure up to the requirements though he will never set the world on fire.

With best regards,

Yours sincerely,

T.F. McIlwraith

P.S. Two other students, whom I do not know, also came in to see me about how to apply for summer jobs. Miss Audrey Tournay, III Pass, 41 Glenbrae Ave., Leaside, tells me that she plans to go to normal school with a view to a teaching job in an Indian school. The other is Miss Lorna Callahan.

OTTAWA, Ontario

December 1, 1949

Gentlemen:

Once again, it is time to start planning for the employment of university students at the end of the academic year. Although many veteran students have already graduated there will still be exceptionally large classes, due to the presence or veterans, in 1950 and 1951. It is obviously important that employment be found for them - permanent for graduates and temporary for undergraduates.

It may seem rather early to introduce this subject but dealing with the problem involves several months' work and an immediate start is therefore imperative. The full resources of this Department and the National Employment Service will be used to assist in filling your requirements and in finding positions for students seeking them. However, your assistance is vital; without it the problem could not be solved. It would be greatly appreciated therefore if you would list your estimated requirements on the enclosed form and return it to the address given at the top of the form. It is requested that, in listing requirements you supply as full information as possible on such items as remuneration, types of training, whether you will consider applicants from all universities or on some more restricted basis, etc. Complete information will greatly assist in efficient selection of applicants.

Even at this early date you will no doubt be able to give a fairly close estimate of the 1950 graduates you will require. It is realized that at this time it may be more difficult to judge exact requirements for summer employees. However, it will be most helpful if you will list known openings now and indicate a date when further information will be available. Officers of the National Employment Service will then get in touch with you at the time indicated.

Should you make a practice of visiting universities to make your own selection of students, this letter will serve as a reminder that it is time to consider your planning on student employment. It is also a request that employers who make a direct approach will nevertheless furnish the National Employment Service with information as to how many students will be engaged so that the general picture of available openings will be known. Lastly, it is to advise you of assistance available from the National Employment Service in such matters as arranging interviews on the campus, etc. At the Prairie universities, full time N.E.S. offices operate on the campuses throughout the academic year. At other universities, N.E.S. liaison officers work in co-operation with university staffs.

When you avail yourself of this service, it would greatly increase the efficiency of the whole scheme if, when positions are filled, you would immediately notify the N.E.S. local office in your city. When this is done, all offices will be notified and be governed accordingly.

Your co-operation in this matter will be of great assistance and will be appreciated by the students themselves and the university authorities, as well as the government organizations concerned.

Yours very truly,

Another interesting subject will be under discussion at the next meeting of the Group, which will be held on Thursday evening, December 9.

WELCOME NEW CANADIANS

MAYOR'S WELCOME TO NEW CANADIANS

On behalf of the people, the City Council and myself, I have much pleasure in welcoming you to our Canadian City. We are glad to have you join our great and happy Canadian family. I feel sure that you have a great contribution to make to our Canadian way of life and that you will appreciate the privileges of our Canadian Dominion, known as Democracy, especially that of an education in our Night School. I trust that you will make good progress in Citizenship and English and that you will thereby enjoy to the full this Great Dominion of Canada, and that you will always enjoy your association with other Canadians.

W. B. Hughes-Games, Mayor,
CITY OF KELOWNA

To all the members of this class in English and Citizenship I give a hearty welcome. You have come to make your home in Canada. We welcome you and want you to be happy and prosperous and to do all you can to help make Canada prosper as the home of free and well satisfied people. These studies will help you to do all these things.

A. S. Matheson, Inspector of Schools
DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION.

I am pleased that we have this opportunity of helping you through our Night School Classes to gain a wider knowledge of this Canada, of ours and our Canadian way of life. Through willingness to attend these classes you are showing your desire to become good Canadians and to take your part in building this great country of ours. We trust that you will benefit from your attendance at these classes, and that the knowledge you will acquire and the associations you will form will be both pleasant and profitable. We are glad to welcome you as New Canadians and we trust that you will make your contribution to the building of a better Canada.

W. J. Logie, Principal

1. Where is Canada? Canada is in North America.

2. How large is Canada? Canada is the second largest country in the world.

3. What are the boundaries of Canada?
   The boundaries of Canada are:
   - West: The Pacific Ocean.
   - North: The Arctic Ocean.
   - East: The Atlantic Ocean.
   - South: The United States.

4. What are the important geographical regions of Canada?
   The five important geographical regions of Canada are:
   1. The Pacific Coast.
   2. The Prairies.
   3. Ontario and Quebec.
   4. The Maritimes.
   5. The Far North.
5. Name the Capital of Canada? The Capital City of Canada is Ottawa.

6. What are the political regions of Canada? The political regions of Canada are the ten provinces:

1. British Columbia
2. Alberta
3. Saskatchewan
4. Manitoba
5. Ontario
6. Quebec
7. New Brunswick
8. Nova Scotia
9. Prince Edward Island
10. Newfoundland

3. Regina - the Capital of Saskatchewan
4. Winnipeg - the Capital of Manitoba
5. Toronto - the Capital of Ontario
6. Quebec City - the Capital of Quebec
7. Fredericton - the Capital of New Brunswick
8. Charlottetown - the Capital of Prince Edward Island
9. Halifax - the Capital of Nova Scotia
10. St. John - the Capital of Newfoundland

8. Name the important rivers of Canada? The Fraser & Columbia, the Peace and Mackenzie Rivers, the Churchill & Saskatchewan Rivers, and the St. Lawrence and Ottawa rivers.

The Great Lakes:

10. Is Canada very rich? Yes, Canada is blessed with vast natural resources.

11. In the production of what commodities does Canada lead the world? Canada leads the world in the production of newsprint, nickel, platinum, asbestos.

12. Is Canada a large exporting nation? Canada is the second largest exporting nation.

13. What is Canada's leading industry? Canada's leading industry is agriculture.

14. How does Canada help the farming industry? Canada maintains a dominion-wide chain of Experimental Farms where you can obtain information about farming problems.

The American Revolution against Britain broke out in 1775 and the invasion of Canada followed.

The French-Canadians remained loyal to Britain and successfully fought with the British against the Americans.

Lord Durham was sent out from England to investigate the trouble.

After a thorough investigation, Lord Durham submitted a famous report to the British Government in 1839.

Lord Durham's Report of 1839 advocated -

The British Government accepted Lord Durham's famous report.

Both the British and French-Canadian reformers in Upper & Lower Canada continued their fight against the power of the Governors and their appointed councils. This fight was peacefully conducted after 1837.

The Reformers triumphed during the famous Baldwin-Lafontaine government with the great Lord Elgin as Governor.

The election of 1847 re-elected the Baldwin-Lafontaine government. The Rebellion Losses Bill was passed, and signed by the Governor (Lord Elgin) in 1849.

The voter receives a ballot of paper from the Deputy Returning Officer, goes to a polling booth compartment, makes a cross opposite the candidate's name of his choice and folds his ballot. It is then deposited in the ballot box.

This is called secret voting because no one sees you mark your ballot, nor is there any way of checking how the voter marked his ballot.

Dear Sir:

I have just received a mimeographed copy of an illustrated primer on Canadian Geography, History, and Government, "What a Canadian Should Know." The questions and answers present highlights of Canada's story in such a way as to show our evolution to self-government and its dependence on individual worth.

I trust that you will overlook any mistakes you may find because the mimeographing was done by students under rather adverse conditions.

The booklet has been well received by the New Canadians for whom it was prepared, and the High School students who were requested numerous copies for their personal use.

Encouraged by the response and the comments of fellow teachers, I have revised the primer several times, and added word study and work book sections. Since I have no means of publishing the revisions, it occurred to me that you might be interested in publishing this booklet for your schools. If you were interested I could get the revised edition typed out and sent to you for examination.

In Kelowna, we have made an attempt to sell Canadian Currency to both New and Old Canadians, and I think that your success has been achieved.

Sir,

The Department directs your attention to the necessity of the most careful examination of application forms in favour of Indian children who are presented for admission to residential schools. I have, therefore, to invite your attention to, and compliance with, the subjoined facts and instructions.

On the "Application for Admission" form the agent signs the following declaration: "I hereby approve of the admission of the above child and certify that he is eligible to be admitted as a grant-earning pupil."

There is a departmental ruling to the effect that half-breed children living the Indian mode of life or a reserve are eligible for admission to the boarding and industrial schools, or, more fully: "While it was not considered that the children of half-breeds proper of Manitoba and the Prairie Provinces should be admitted into Indian schools and paid for by the Department, it was conceded that all children, even those of mixed blood, whether legitimate or not, who live upon an Indian reserve and whose parents or other siblings live as Indians, even if they are not entitled to vote, should be eligible for admission to the schools. However, every case must be handled against every application for admission should be accompanied by satisfactory evidence that the applicant is a half-breed to whom the rule applies, and not a person who has been adopted by or otherwise brought into association with Indians with the express purpose of gaining admission to our schools."

At the time you forward an application, write a covering letter in the case of half-breed or non-Treaty children, giving your reasons for believing the child to be a charge on the Indian Department.

When you have reason to believe that the accommodation of the boarding or industrial school is limited, preference should be given to orphan children or those that are neglected by their parents.

Exercise every care to ensure the placing of the child in a residential school under the auspices of the religious denomination to which the parents adhere. No Roman Catholic child shall be sent to a Protestant school, and vice versa. You will please adhere strictly to this provision of the Act. (See Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act). Concerning the age of applicants for admission to our residential schools, only in very exceptional cases will the Department authorize the admission of any child other than between the ages of 7 and 13 inclusive.

Check carefully all applications that come before you, giving particular attention to the age, religion and status of the applicant before asking the Department to admit them as grant-earning pupils to a Boarding or Industrial school.

Dear Editor,

Please be good enough to read and accept this article.

I should be glad to take up any copies of the publication containing it. Yours sincerely H.L.Bergman.

III.

What is the best method of teaching primitive people?

The same as that of teaching primitive children, not by making them listen to lectures but by making them work.

They should take an active part in the work of the class.

Postures are more important than words. Doing something is more important than listening to a lecture.

Daily exercise will improve their health.

They should know something about the geography of the world and move from place to place, from country to country.

In this way they will easily learn all that they are being taught.

I applied these principles in my world-class. For this reason I bought a plot of ground (50 yards long by 30 yards wide) in 1908.

The pupils of my class laid out a world-garden. In it this garden was, as it were, a large map of the world.

Each of the pupils had a little plot of ground of his own which represented a certain country.

They sold the products of their own countries and, if possible, grew them in their own gardens.

The world and their own countries were their "textbooks" for years and years.

In this way every teacher can use his own textbook.

The pupils will be more receptive than in the old class.

They will work in this world and the teacher will give them a useful general knowledge of this world instead of a dangerous knowledge of special subjects.

H.L.Bergman, Holland, 1-1-49.
What is the best method of teaching primitive people?

The same as that of teaching primitive children which method is this? The method of working hard. The best method for primitives demands few new words and ideas, no jumping from one thing to another, one structure, only one building-up-factor, which word unites the education from the primitives to farther, practically and theoretically. This word is "work". Movement, hard work is the base of the worldclass. Why an education without base? Without fundament? One word, unitywork is needed. The worldgarden will give an idea of this work.

How to make clear that hard work is needed? How to make clear that hard work is needed for the rise of peoples? The answer is: by numbers. Numbers which demonstrate that hard work is the corner-stone of the building (rising) of generations and the world. Numbers as hardily-factors... not by making them listen to lectures but by making them work. They should take an active part in the work of the school. Gestures are more important than words. Especially primitives are poor in words, but movements can say much. A gesture to ear, eye, or mouth can say sentences like: hear, see, be silent.

The method of movements becomes productive, instead of reproductive. For in the art of teaching, the great art of teaching primitives, can these movements be made ten times more instructive? By movements in the worldgarden, the world is reviewed from 20 different points of view. (Branches of the curriculum).

There is consequently some repetition which will serve a useful purpose as revision and production, instead of reproduction. Idleness is the root of all evil. Movements are the root of saying, writing, eating, breathing. To see and say sentences like the above mentioned is double as instructive. The productive method is worth twice as much as the reproductive. Movements from place to place can be doubled as instructive again, for the memory of place is the strongest, especially with primitives. Even flat movements are tenfold instructive within the worldclass.

Movements can be twice as instructive as reproduction from books. Four times more instructive can be evoluted, when going from place to place. This quadruple instructiveness is doubled if the place lies in a fixed, regular, symmetric structure like the worldclass. These movements for primitive is ten times more instructive than the reproductive idea of teaching.

A number of experts have come to this conclusion here.

I put these principles into practice in my worldgarden and worldclass. For this reason I bought a plot of ground (50 yards long by 30 yards) in 1968, the pupils of my class laid out a worldgarden in it. This garden was, as it were, a large map of the world. Every pupil occupies his country, has his place, which is indicated by a number denoting the longitude and latitude of the country. On a square or field if need be without frontiers this plain or field represents the world as a world-wide farmland representing the grasslands, etc., in 32 countries in 30 places or pupils on the field or in the classroom without the gap-character.

Given without frontiers for the world the class can play there all branches. The pupils are the food, flatively or in reality. They are instructed in order to become servants of the Uncsoo. They sell their product and keep their book (book-keeping).

How to make the reproductive method productive? One of the pupils e.g. lives in San Francisco, California; his name is chosen from the environment and his surname, last from one of its products. Cal Fut. From this name the class evolves a sentence from 33 names, 23 sentences, self-made. This lesson in 10 tens, 10 persons, 10 forms, with 10 determinations (adjectives), consequently so in 10,000 forms is an introduction to the book "The World".

Afterwards in 4 languages. Every teacher can type and multiply his own book. His mind has a natural tendency to reject the other books. Translations of the book are to be learned in one tenth of the time, for the movements are known, the succession, the composition too.

Stadskaan, Holland, .. H.J.Bergman. 1-9-49.
School, food and people.

Fundamental education. Movement is the fundament.

How are we to fight famine in this devastated world? How are we to cultivate enough food for the rapidly increasing population of the world? How are we to secure a higher standard of living? How can we prevent slumps and unemployment? In short how can we build a better world, create mutual understanding and secure a feeling of safety?

By a change in food production. Hard work. The change that would most increase food production would be to transform the present predominantly peasant type of rural economy to a mixed farm type as adopted in the more advanced countries.

While increases in food production can be confidently expected, they will certainly involve considerable work and much scientific study. There is no prospect of easy living.

100 million of people suffer from food shortage now.

Every year the population of the world increases by 1%. But every year the area of food-producing soil decreases by 2%.

What will the situation be like after a century? After a comparatively short time the population will be doubled, the cultivated soil halved, the need quadruples.

How can double the population be fed on half the cultivated soil?

This is possible, if:

- first - the food shortage is fought now,
- secondly - the farmer-to-be (peasant) not is disaccustomed from hard work, from vigorous movements,
- thirdly - the farmers are given an agricultural-scientific education, prepared in the primary school,
- fourthly - we prevent the hoarding of food for the next war, if the world restore this as world as unity.

In 1870 the war was won by the teacher. In 1970 the war will be won by the teacher who gives his pupils a good technical education (electricity, etc.). The pupils should be taught, not only to fight in a military war, but also to fight food-shortage and unemployment.

Unemployment increases with the poverty in the world. The more-sold of the U.S.A. was every year 400 million dollars.

In June 1949 there were four millions of unemployed laborers.

This proves that even the richest nation of the world cannot fight unemployment successfully in its own country.

Unemployment is an international problem.

If new agricultural countries produce and sell more agricultural products, they can buy more and fight unemployment.

How to increase this production? In 1650 Mr. van Hoek came to Noord-Brabant, a province of the Netherlands, as a teacher of agriculture. At that time there was only one dairy-factory in the whole province. In 1877 there were 125 dairy-factories, with a large export-trade, and less unemployment also in the other parts.

To increase the number of these factories in this district from 1 to 125 takes up less energy and time than to raise that number from 125 to 250. Therefore the best plan is to begin with the development of undeveloped regions. Unesco tries to educate the backward nations. They should be quickly educated. Their soil should be cultivated and their agriculture be developed.

This is an international experiment of the greatest importance, because national experiments are bound to fail.

Sound agricultural instruction is essential. The guidance of the Unesco is necessary. The agricultural instruction should be adapted to the country where it is given already in the primary school. Physics and biology should more frequently be taught.

The elementary school will give this preparation without to be technical. With the view to education in agriculture and hygiene the class is as a worldwide mixed farm in the classroom. The pupils, the desks are the countries, small countries, symmetric, regular, in the same structure as the numbers. One structure and not more.

By more structures there are orders and contra-orders with the physical distress, the psychological press with the stuttering, with the destroy instead of the consumption.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to my letter of the 16 July 1949, with which I forwarded you a copy of the Resolution on conditions of life and work of indigenous populations adopted by the Fourth Conference of American States Members of the International Labour Organisation (Montevideo, April-May 1949), and to my letter of 28 September 1949, in which I informed you of the questions which the Governing Body of the International Labour Office had decided to place on the agenda of the first meeting of the Committee on Indigenous Labour.

In accordance with point 3 of the above-mentioned Resolution and in pursuance of the decision of the Governing Body, the Office is assembling first-hand information on the experience acquired by various countries with respect to indigenous workers, with special reference to (1) development of programmes of vocational training; (2) recruitment of indigenous agricultural labourers and mine workers; (3) extension of social insurance and other forms of social assistance; (4) protection of indigenous homesteads; and (5) safety in industry, and in particular in mining undertakings.

This information will be utilised in the preparation of reports on these questions which the Office will submit to the Committee on Indigenous Labour.

In order that the information on the situation in your country may be accurate and complete, I venture to request that you may be so good as to forward to the Office as soon as possible a memorandum on the economic and social conditions of indigenous workers in your country and the measures which your Government has taken or proposes to take in the near future for the benefit of those workers, with respect to the five points mentioned above, in so far as they are relevant to conditions in your country.

It would be greatly appreciated if you would include in the memorandum information on the following points: - (a) the definition, as given in Federal or Provincial legislation, of the terms "indigenous", "indigenous population", "aboriginal" or "aboriginal population"; (b) approximate number of the indigenous population and the proportion which it represents of the total population of the country; (c) regions or districts in which the indigenous population is chiefly located; (d) approximate occupational distribution of the indigenous population in relation to the chief occupations and regions and the proportion which it represents of the total number of the gainfully employed population of the country; (e) general health of the indigenous population, with an indication of the nature and frequency of the chief illnesses and the medical and health services available in regions inhabited by indigenous groups; and (f) illiteracy among the indigenous population.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient Servant,

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY

Re: International Labour Office

In the beginning, Indian Affairs introduced Indian boys and girls activities by an integrated programme of studies. Following its first phase Indian boys and girls are gradually introduced to special training - the boys to shop work which includes mechanics, woodwork, gardening, farming, metalwork and leatherwork - the girls to Domestic Science which includes cooking, housekeeping, sewing, weaving, gardening and leatherwork. As soon as these students show aptitude and desire they are placed in provincial or privately operated trade schools. Indian girls and boys have been encouraged to complete their academic training and take business training such as nursing and teaching. The Department employs Indian teachers in its own schools, while a number of Indians are teaching in provincial schools. The Department also employs Indians in its other services.

Indian Affairs endeavours to guide Indian pupils into channels for which they are best suited. In many cases these Indian children adjust themselves quite well to the new method of life and are making successes of their careers.

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor of Vocational Education.
MEMORANDUM TO THE SECRETARY

RE: International Labour Office.

With regard to your request of December 17 for details of the development of programs of vocational training among indigenous populations, I am pleased to submit the following report:

Indian boys and girls are introduced to vocational activities by an integrated program of studies. Following this first phase, these pupils are gradually introduced to special training. The boys begin their shop work which includes mechanics, woodwork, metal work, leather work, gardening and farming. The girls begin their various activities in domestic science which include cooking, housekeeping, sewing, weaving and gardening.

Any students showing special aptitudes and desires are placed in provincial or privately operated trade schools. Often these are schools receiving funds through the Canadian Vocational Training Plan. Those boys and girls who take well to secondary education, are encouraged to complete their academic training and we particularly try to guide them into two professions, namely nursing and teaching.

There is a great need for nurses and teachers on their home reserves and we feel that trained Indian workers can accomplish much in improving home conditions, etc. The Department now employs about 50 Indian teachers in its own schools while
a number of Indians are teaching in provincial schools. Some Indian girls are now employed in the hospitals of the Department of National Health and Welfare as nurses while others have been trained as nurses' aides. Our Branch endeavours to guide Indian pupils into channels for which they are best suited. In many cases these Indian children adjust themselves quite well to this different mode of life and become assimilated into the communities of Canada.

REDUCTION IN ESTIMATES

When the Deputy Minister and yourself are called before the Treasury Board, I would strongly suggest that you might point out to them the changes which education, particularly in a day school, can bring to an Indian community. The attached newspaper article describes the work of our welfare teacher at Fort McPherson. Three years ago there was no school at Fort McPherson and most of these Indians had never been educated.

I will let Miss Hinds' article describe the changes which have resulted since the little day school has been established for these Indians and their children. I would emphasize that we are trying to do more than merely educating the Indian children. This article should convince the members of the Treasury Board that communities such as this are desperately in need of educational facilities - we have been able to provide them at Fort McPherson - we can only provide them at similar Indian communities elsewhere if funds are available. Mr. Bryce and the other members of the Treasury Board might also read with profit the article which recently appeared in the Toronto Star on "Higher Education at Caughnawaga". There they will read how we are trying to educate the Indians of the southern regions into Canadian citizenship. There our problem is entirely different and it is a matter of providing facilities for higher education for Indians rather than the simple elementary education provided in such places as Fort McPherson.

It might be also pointed out that our schools have for years lagged behind the provincial schools. We are now

CORRESPONDENCE COURSE IN OFFICE MANAGEMENT

GENERAL INFORMATION

1. Origin of this course:

This course came into being as a result of a recommendation made by a sub-committee of the Interdepartmental Committee on Staff Training. It was originally prepared by Officers of the staff of the Comptroller of the Treasury and presented to their employees holding supervisory positions. It has now been revised by the Staff Training Division of the Civil Service Commission to adapt it for presentation to Civil Servants throughout the various government departments across the country.

2. Purpose of the course:

The course has been designed to give personnel employed in a supervisory capacity and personnel who look forward to such responsibilities, some practical instruction in management techniques to help them acquire the knowledge and ability to handle an executive position more efficiently.

3. Structure of the course:

a) Papers - The revised course is made up of twenty papers with a detachable assignment at the end of each. These assignments are of the objective type, namely: True-False, Multiple Choice, Completion or Matching types. A proper time limit for the completion of each assignment is two weeks. In this way every registrant will be able to have completed the necessary papers by the dates set for the Term-Tests. The corrected assignments will not be returned to candidates.

b) Term Tests - A mid-term test will be forwarded to each candidate immediately after Paper X has been completed. This test will be of the Essay Type and candidates will have two weeks to handle it. To be eligible to write this test, all of assignments 1 to 10 inclusive must have been received for correction by the Staff Training Division of the Civil Service Commission, Ottawa.

A Final Test will be administered under supervision at specified centres across Canada. This test will be held about two weeks after completion of Paper XX. This test will also be of the Essay Type and will be devised to ascertain whether candidates have applied or can apply to specific tasks the principles advocated in the course. To be eligible for this Final Test, all of assignments 11 to 20 as well as Mid Term must have been completed by each candidate.

4. How to study:

Instructional matter contained in each paper should be mastered fully before attempting the assignment at the end of each paper. Likewise, time spent on studying references listed below would be time well spent. The assignments are done on your own and you should be able to answer questions without back-tracking to the paper itself. This is most important in order to derive maximum benefit from each paper. Where two or more candidates are located in the same area they may benefit by setting up a study group of their own. Suggested topics for such study groups are to be found at the end of each paper.
5. References

Many interesting and enlightening books have been written on Office Management and Personnel Management. It is recommended that you study at least a few of these to supplement instructional matter contained in the twenty papers. Students are referred to the following which are probably available in departmental or public libraries.

The Office Supervisor - by Henry E. Niles and Mary C.H. Niles published by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

Textbook of Office Management - by Leffingwell and Robinson published by McGraw-Hill Book Co.

Manual of Practical Office Short Cuts - by National Office Management Assoc., published by McGraw-Hill Book Co.

Office Management - a handbook by Coleman L. Mass published by Ronald Press

Human Factors in Management - by Schuyler Dean Hoslett published by Harper & Brothers

Practical Office Supervision - by Glenn L. Gardiner published by McGraw-Hill Book Co.

Personnel Management - by Walter Dill Scott published by McGraw-Hill Book Co.

Psychology for Business and Industry - by Herbert Moore published by McGraw-Hill Book Co.

Personnel Administration - by Tead and Metcalf published by McGraw-Hill Book Co.

6. Ratings

Ratings will be based on the twenty assignments and the two term tests. An official certificate will be issued to successful candidates by the Staff Training Division of the Civil Service Commission.

PROGRAMME OF STUDIES FOR INDIAN SCHOOLS

The programme of studies herein prescribed shall be followed by the teacher as far as the circumstances of the school permit. Any modifications deemed necessary should be made only with the sanction of the Branch.

Textbooks: While in the case of most subjects, Provincial textbooks are used, it should be noted that the Indian Affairs Branch prescribes certain books which have been found specially suitable for Indian Schools. Particulars regarding these books may be obtained on application to the Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Requisitions: When preparing requisitions for school material ask only for those texts authorized above. The Indian Affairs Branch requires you to adhere strictly to this rule. Teachers will please note the instructions on the "Requisition for School Material" form No. 413. Indian agents will supply these forms.

TEACHING — NOTE THE FOLLOWING SUGGESTIONS

Language: Every effort must be made to induce pupils to speak English and to teach them to understand it. Insist on English even during the supervised play. Failure in this means wasted efforts. (In some schools in Quebec, where French is the classroom language, the word "French" should be substituted in the above instruction where the word "English" appears.)

Reading: Do not hear the children read, teach them to read. Do not use the phonics method to teach beginners unless it is for children with serious disabilities. Remember reading is a basic skill. Great care should be taken to teach it properly. The primary division members should be grouped and regrouped for reading practice upon the basis of their reading ability and not upon the time spent in school. Pupils should be tested at the beginning of each year and grouped accordingly. Apply remedial measures whenever necessary.

Vocational: Teachers are expected to emphasize the importance of vocational instruction—rural. Dressmaking, crochet work, knitting, hand loom weaving, elementary domestic science, gardening and care of poultry are recommended for girls; and elementary carpentry work, general shop, Indian handicrafts, gardening, and poultry raising for boys. At residential schools the care of live stock, auto mechanics and cultivation of land should be emphasized. Cultivation should conform to the requirements of the home of each pupil. This is especially true of residential schools where pupils come from different reserves.

Physical: Lay stress on physical activities that will strengthen the body and improve health. Special attention should be given to outdoor group games, supervised play and exercises, accompanied by singing, to afford variation and improve physique.

Vocal Music: Simple songs and hymns; the theme of the former to be interesting and patriotic; the tunes bright and cheerful.

Religious: Scriptural reading, the Ten Commandments, the Lord's Prayer, the Instruction: Life of Christ, etc.

Character: Teachers will strive to develop the spirit of responsibility among the children, giving responsibility in turn, even in small things; gathering books, pencils, etc., for the smaller ones. Give greater responsibility as the child advances in age. Demand success and tactfully reprimand failures. Teachers will stress obedience, courtesy, cleanliness, self-respect, thrift, self-maintenance and patriotism. Cultivate honesty and the spirit of fair play. Teach respect of law, order, authority and public property. Explain the relation of the same as to labour, laws and public duties.
The object of health education is to have the pupils form worthwhile habits. Habits cannot be taught in the traditional way as book-learning, but must be acquired by constant practice. Methods must be worked out by the teacher, who will have the pupils make health posters, join classroom health activities and health games, etc. It is of the utmost importance that Indian pupils be taught to recognize the value of a well-balanced diet. Recommend the use of meat, milk and vegetables. The teacher should stress the relationship of such diet to physical fitness, growth and general health.

Great care must be exercised by the teacher to see that the school-room is kept thoroughly clean. The floor should be swept daily and scrubbed frequently. The air in the schoolroom should be completely changed during recesses and at the noon hour, even in the coldest weather, by the opening of windows and doors. Spitting on the floor, or inside the school building, should not be allowed. Cleanliness in the classroom as well as in the surrounding buildings and school yard is a definite phase of health education. Great stress will be emphasized on these by the teacher.

General: Whenever possible the teachers will employ the activity program. Teachers must keep in mind that the text-book is but an educational instrument. Pupils must be well grouped according to their ability. Objective achievement tests should be used as frequently as necessary.

School Hours - Day Schools

Reference your 112-6-3 of February 21

The hours of instruction and the arrangements for religious instruction will normally be the same as for schools under provincial control.

During most of the year in Indian schools the hours will be:

Mornings 9.00 - 12.00
Afternoons 1.30 - 4.00

Through November, December, January and February by arrangement between the Superintendent and the teachers the hours may be as follows:

Mornings 9.30 - 12.00
Afternoons Terminating at 3.30

You will note the exceptions that may arise concerning the length of the noon intermission. During the months when the weather is severe and the daylight of shorter duration, as the children usually bring lunch to school, the noon intermission is usually reduced to one hour. In other months a longer noon intermission is usual, and it is expected that there will be supervised play.
It may be, however, that at some schools in your jurisdiction there exist certain conditions which require modification of the length of the noon hour. You should discuss these with the teacher and decide upon the schedule which seems to suit the particular situation best, so that, allowing for a recess of 15 minutes each morning and each afternoon, the hours of instruction may be:

|        | Summer | Winter |
|--------|--------|--------|
| Mornings | 2½ hours | 2½ hours |
| Afternoons | 2½ hours | 1½ hours |

Denominational religious instruction is allowable for one-half hour session each week. EDUCATION OF CANADA'S INDIANS

(Summary of talk given to the Professional Institute of the Civil Service of Canada on March 13, 1950, by B.F. Henry, Superintendent of Education, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration.)

Due to the time limit of ten minutes the speaker divided his talk into ten questions and answers covering the points most commonly asked about Indian education.

1. Q. How many schools are operated by this Division?

A. There are nearly 450 day school classrooms in operation, mainly one-room schools; there are 70 residential schools, 7 hospital schools and about 20 seasonal schools. There are also a few schools jointly operated with the provinces.

2. Q. How many children are receiving education in these various schools?

A. About 23,500.

3. Q. What kind of schools are operated by your Division?

A. The day schools are for Indians living on settled reserves. The residential schools are for welfare cases and the children of Indians whose parents earn their living by trapping and similar occupations. The hospital schools are for both children and adults in Indian hospitals. The seasonal schools are for Indians particularly in Northern Quebec and Ontario, who come out to trading posts for three or four months in the summer holidays. The joint schools are increasing in number and are operated for both Indians and Whites.

4. Q. Where are these schools situated?

A. They are located in each of the provinces, in the Northwest Territories and the Yukon. The majority of the schools are in Ontario and British Columbia, which two provinces have the largest Indian populations.

5. Q. How are the Day schools operated?

A. By the Department with teachers being classified as Civil Servants mostly on a seasonal basis (ten month year).

6. Q. How are the Residential schools operated?

A. These are conducted for the Department by various religious denominations. A per capita grant is paid for the maintenance and education of each Indian child.

7. Q. How many teachers of various types do you hire?

A. There are over 450 teachers hired with nearly 400 being classified as school teachers and 30 as welfare teachers. These latter teach in the hospital schools and on isolated reserves where their duties are many and varied. We also hire a number of seasonal school teachers and part-time teachers.
6. Q. What curriculum do you follow?

A. With few exceptions we conform to that of the province in which the school is located. Special emphasis is of course paid to health and physical education and the stress in social studies is on Canadian history and geography.

9. Q. What are your urgent educational problems?

A. (a) Supervision and inspection of a widely scattered school system.
(b) The building of schools in isolated districts.
(c) The hiring of good teachers when the schools are isolated and so far from stores, doctors, etc.

10. Q. How many Indians are receiving tuition benefits for higher education?

A. There are nearly 400 Indian children receiving provincial secondary education including vocational training, teacher training and enrolled in university courses. There are also nearly 200 Indian children enrolled in secondary grades in our own schools.

INDIAN EDUCATION 1939-1949

Many changes have taken place in Indian education during the past 10 years. The following statistics will show the growth of the Indian school population during that time:

| Fiscal Year | Residential Schools | Day Schools | Total (All Schools) |
|-------------|---------------------|-------------|--------------------|
|             | Enrolment | Average Attendance | Enrolment | Average Attendance | Enrolment | Average Attendance | Percentage of Attendance |
| 1939-40     | 9,179      | 8,276       | 9,573      | 6,232              | 16,752    | 14,508            | 77.36                  |
| 1940-41     | 9,348      | 8,345       | 12,511     | 10,320             | 21,863    | 18,759            | 85.33                  |

You will note that the total includes more than the pupils at the residential and the day schools as there are a number of children attending joint schools.

The greatest growth in school population has taken place during the past 3 years. For example, in the year ending March 1949, the enrolment at day schools had increased by 1,529 pupils.

In addition to the 21,863 pupils shown above, there were 925 Indian children in elementary grades and 377 in secondary grades in provincial schools. This meant a total of 23,165 Indian pupils enrolled in educational classes. It is difficult to accurately estimate the number of school age children until the next census is completed. The 1944 census showed 28,429 children between the ages
of 7 and 16. It is therefore safe to estimate that there are now about 35,000 of school age. This means that there are over 7,000 children for whom no educational facilities are yet provided.

Percentage of Attendance

During the past few years there has been a steady increase in the percentage attendance. This is particularly noticeable in Indian day schools where formerly the pupils attended irregularly. The day school attendance, however, is now improving steadily as a result of family allowances paid, the better calibre of teachers employed, the improvements in classroom techniques and equipment, and finally the awakening interest of Indian parents in the education of their children. We intend to stimulate this interest by the formation of Parent-Teacher groups, adult education classes, and other community movements.

Education in Association with other Children

In accordance with the recommendations of the Joint Parliamentary Committee, we have been accomplishing major changes in having more Indian children admitted to white schools. In British Columbia alone the number has increased from about 200 in September 1948 to nearly 700 in September 1949. We will continue to work towards the admission of more Indian children to provincial schools in accordance with the recommendation of the Committee.

Erection of New Schools

The number of new schools erected can best be illustrated by the fact that the Department hired 285 day school teachers in 1946 and is now employing nearly 450. This growth represents the opening of new schools and also additions to existing facilities.

At residential schools we have erected several classroom blocks and one dormitory block. One new residential school is presently under construction and the tender has been let for the erection of another. Both of these are in northern Canada.
Improvement in the calibre of teachers

Unless good teachers are appointed to fill the new classrooms being provided, educational progress among the Indians will not continue to improve. Therefore, the Department has been constantly weeding out unqualified and insufficient teachers and replacing them with certificated teachers as conditions permit.

In spite of the great teacher shortage which presently exists, we have been able to accomplish a great deal during the past 3 years. A review of the situation can best be presented graphically as follows:

| Day School Teacher Percentages | January 1948 | January 1950 |
|-------------------------------|--------------|--------------|
| Grade 1 (Third Class or No certificate) | 34 % | 22 % |
| Grade 2 (Second Class Certificate) | 30 % | 25 % |
| Grade 3 (First Class Certificate) | 27 % | 39 % |
| Grade 4, Principals and Welfare Teachers | 9 % | 14 % |

To summarize the above statistics, you will note that we have reduced the number of non-certified teachers from one third of our staff to nearly one fifth of our staff in a space of 3 years. During the same time we have increased the number of teachers with First Class Certificates from 27% to 39%.

Secondary Education

There has been a steady increase in the number of Indian children who are enrolled in the secondary grades. In the academic year ending June 1949 there were 777 children in high school grades in provincial schools and 284 in our own schools.

Memorandum:

COLONEL ACLAND

Education of Indians

Please find attached a statement of statistics which should do a great deal to correct the misstatements made by Brigadier Martin.

The figures show that we have reduced now to about 6 or 7000, the number of children for whom educational facilities are provided. The number of day school classrooms has risen from 285 to nearly 450 within the last three years.

We can not provide statistics for the qualifications of teachers in residential schools as these are controlled by the denominations concerned. In the day schools, however, we can definitely report on the improved qualifications of our teachers.

In 1948 we hired 352 day school teachers of whom 120 (or 34%) had only teaching permits, licenses or no certificate. We had 97 teachers (or 28%) with First Class Certificates and 120 (or 34%) with Second Class Certificates.

In January 1950 we were hiring 432 teachers of whom 95 (or 22%) were Grade 1 teachers, 172 (or 40%) were Grade 3 teachers and 109 (or 26%) were Grade 2 teachers.

A review of this situation can be presented graphically hereunder:

| Teachers | January 1948 | January 1950 |
|----------|--------------|--------------|
| Grade 1  | 34%          | 22%          |
| Grade 2  | 32%          | 26%          |
Teachers

January 1948 | January 1950
---|---
Grade 3 | 28% | 40%
Grade 4, Principals and Welfare teachers | 6% | 12%

In other words, we have reduced the number of non-qualified teachers from 1/3 of our staff to 1/5 in a space of two years. We have increased the number of teachers with First Class Certificates from 28% to 40%.

SECONDARY EDUCATION

We have noted Brigadier Martin's statement concerning part-time education. This did apply to our schools three years ago but we have greatly reduced the number of schools in which the children are not fully occupied in classroom work. By the introduction of labor-saving devices such as peeler peelers, washing machines etc. and by the large increase in the per capita grants we have attempted to make the school management less dependent on the use of children for work in the schools.

CONCLUSION

As I was dictating the above information, there was placed on my desk a letter from the Canadian Education Association outlining the shortage of teachers in schools across Canada. Several provinces report schools closed because of the lack of teachers and the number opened but without qualified teachers is indeed a revelation. There are 750 such schools in Nova Scotia, 703 in Saskatchewan, 609 in New Brunswick, 603 in Manitoba and even 300 in Ontario. I, therefore, feel that our day schools have little to be criticized in this regard.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

The hours of instruction and the arrangements for religious instruction will normally be the same as for schools under provincial control.

During most of the year in Indian schools the hours will be:

Mornings 9.00 - 12.00
Afternoons 1.30 - 4.00

Through November, December, January and February by arrangement between the Superintendent and the teachers the hours may be as follows:

Mornings 9.30 - 12.00
Afternoons Terminating at 3.30

You will note the exceptions that may arise concerning the length of the noon intermission. During the months when the weather is severe and the daylight of shorter duration, as the children usually bring lunch to school, the noon intermission is usually reduced to one hour. In other months a longer noon intermission is usual, and it is expected that there will be supervised play.
It may be, however, that at some schools in your jurisdiction there exist certain conditions which require modification of the length of the noon hour. You should discuss these with the teacher and decide upon the schedule which seems to suit the particular situation best, so that, allowing for a recess of 15 minutes each morning and each afternoon, the hours of instruction may be:

|       | Summer | Winter |
|-------|--------|--------|
| Mornings | 2\(\frac{3}{4}\) hours | 2\(\frac{1}{4}\) hours |
| Afternoons | 2\(\frac{1}{4}\) hours | 1\(\frac{1}{4}\) hours |

Denominational religious instruction is allowable for one-half hour session each week. This period is to be regularly scheduled, and you should arrange, accordingly, with the missionary workers and teachers concerned that the visits of the missionaries adhere to a regular schedule i.e., always on the same week day and at the same time, preferably the last half-hour of the afternoon session.

Where there are two or more denominational groups, arrangements should be made for them to receive instruction simultaneously. For example at Hobbsma the United Church minority could receive instruction in the nearby manse. At Louis Bull the Roman Catholic minority could be sent to the nearby mission. At Montana there is no minority to be considered.

Your attention is invited to the Department's suggestions to teachers as printed on the back cover of the register. A copy of these suggestions is attached. Under "Religious Instruction" an indication is given of the inter-denominational religious instruction recommended for those schools where denominational differences are...
not accentuated and where specialists are not available to give instruction. In implementing these suggestions the teacher must ensure that nothing is included in the opening exercises or other lessons to all the pupils that would be a cause for disharmony.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR:

Regional Inspectors of Indian Schools

Since our conversation of yesterday evening, I have just received a letter from Mr. Ostrander, our Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for Saskatchewan.

As a result of a letter sent to him by me, Mr. Ostrander has had each of his Superintendents submit a report on the various Day School teachers in their agencies. On the basis of these reports he is recommending the dismissal of eight teachers. I can best present his viewpoint by quoting from his letter as follows:

"In each case the Indian Superintendent has given his frank opinion of the teacher, and in no case do I feel inclined to disagree with him. It is my opinion that the following teachers should be replaced at the beginning of the next term:

Absalom Halkett, Shoal Lake Indian Day School,
Mr. John L. Lowe, Red Earth Indian Day School,
Mrs. W.F. Donaghy, Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School,
Mrs. M. Burbridge, James Smith North Indian Day School,
Mr. James A. Gardner, Kinistino Indian Day School,
Mr. F.C. Monaghan, Poorman's Indian Day School,
Mr. Robert Hick, Bay Star Indian Day School,
Mr. G.R.J. Chouinard, Meadow Lake Indian Day School

Consideration might also be given to replacing Mr. W.F. Cavanaugh, at the St. Francis Indian Day School. Mr. Cavanaugh is doing fairly good work, but is quite aged, and is doing nothing but strictly classroom work."
I believe that the time has been reached when we should discontinue employing aged teachers at Indian day schools. It is beginning to appear to me that Saskatchewan teachers are now realizing that salaries at Indian day schools are fairly good, and the number of applications from well qualified teachers is gradually increasing. However, there is also another increase which is not so promising, and that is the increase in the number of teachers who, having retired from Saskatchewan schools, on pension try to get into our service. If they are too old to teach white schools they are certainly too old to teach Indian schools. It is time for us to start weeding out our present employed aged teachers and to refuse to accept any more of them. In this connection I refer particularly to such cases as the case of Mrs. B.G. Eugenie Thomas, referred to in Department letter of March 17th, 1926, File 1-1-1-(3), who is applying for a teaching position, and such teachers as Miss Moore, Mrs. Stewart, Mr. Donahy, Mrs. Burbridge, Mr. Cavanaugh, Mr. Gardner, Mr. Monaghan, and Mr. Hick, to mention some of them.

We need teachers with their careers in front of them, rather than behind them. This fact is especially emphasized at this time because of the fact that our teachers, if young and well qualified, can become permanent Civil Servants, making a career of their work, and having a substantial superannuation at the end. There is also the other important factor which must be considered, and that is the fact that most of these teachers who have retired from Provincial schools have done so because they were too old to want to, or be able to, comply with new and improved teaching methods. They come to our service hoping that we are so old fashioned that we won't ask them to change their methods. If there is any one thing needed more than any other thing in our Indian education, it is a willingness to continually change for the better.
It is very difficult for elderly people to change, at least they do not, whether we hope they will, or not."

When you are discussing this matter with the Deputy Minister I feel that Mr. Ostrander's views should be presented to him.

It is very difficult for the Department to decide in each of these eight cases as some of the teachers may be doing good work in the classroom but not impressing the Indian Superintendents in other ways. Naturally our Indian Superintendents are not professional educators and are not qualified to report upon the teaching efficiency of these various teachers. This places me in a difficult predicament in that we have only non-commissioned Provincial School Inspectors' reports on most of these teachers. I need a frank report from one of my own School Inspectors so that a proper decision can be reached on the proposed replacement of each of these eight teachers.

We are now employing 478 teachers in this Division, and with no adequate supervision system, it is becoming increasingly difficult to maintain the efficiency of our educational system. The need for these Regional Inspectors is so apparent that even the Civil Service Commission Investigator has recommended the establishment of such positions.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
