MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

ONTARIO EDUCATIONAL ASSOCIATION MEETING -
APRIL 10, 11 and 12,

As requested by our previous Deputy Minister, I am pleased to submit the following report on my attendance at the above meeting:

1. Ontario School Inspectors' Association

This meeting took place on Monday April 10 and as usual, the officials from this Branch were made welcome to these meetings which are restricted otherwise to Ontario school inspectors. The main discussion was on the new curricula for grades 7, 8 and 9. Reports were received from the various committees which had been established for each subject of the courses of study. There was heated discussion from the floor concerning the revised curriculum and we were able to get valuable advanced information concerning the changes in the Ontario course of study.

At the annual luncheon of the Ontario School Inspectors' Association we were very pleased with the reception given to the choir from the Six Nations No. 2 Indian Day School. There were only 6 girls in this group but they performed most admirably under the direction of their teacher, Miss Jamieson. We received many personal compliments from the school inspectors after the luncheon concerning the fine singing of these Indian girls.
2. Education Association Lectures

The three outstanding lectures were given by Dr. A. S. Artley of the University of Missouri, Sir Alfred Zimmern of Oxford University and the Honourable Dana Porter, Minister of Education for Ontario.

Dr. Artley is a specialist in the teaching of the language arts and his two lectures on "Helping Children Become Independent in Word Attack" and "Vocabulary Development" were most applicable to our Indian schools. I was able to obtain valuable notes and will later write an article for our Indian School Bulletin on the information thus received.

Sir Alfred Zimmern's lecture was on "Education for Life in the Atomic Age". His address was given before several thousand people and was an outstanding example of the ability of a trained lecturer to hold the attention of even a large audience. His philosophy of education is exemplary for all teachers in a democracy and his lecture left a vivid impression of the importance of the work of the teacher.

The Honourable Mr. Porter's address was concerned with the new curriculum for Ontario.

I also attended other lectures on social studies in the primary grades and on rhythmical activities in the junior grades.

3. Meetings with Officials of the Ontario Department of Education.

As every school inspector is required to attend this meeting, I was naturally able to solve many problems with regard to our many Indian day schools in this province. Their co-operation is always most keenly appreciated and much correspondence can be avoided by this annual meeting.

I attended a meeting with Dr. Brown, the Registrar of Teachers, and Mr. Elborn, the Superintendent of Professional Training. At the present time, teachers in Ontario can obtain teaching certificates after two years of teaching, two good
inspectors' reports and two professional summer schools. However, such teachers are required to sign a statement certifying that they will teach for at least one year in a provincial school after obtaining such a certificate.

I was able to gain a valuable concession from this regulation and in future our Indian school teachers will be able to obtain certificates without signing such a declaration. As I have at least five teachers in this predicament now, I feel that this effort was indeed worthwhile.

I also met Dr. Gannau, the Superintendent of Elementary Education, concerning joint schools in the northern part of the province, and Mr. J. C. Walsh, concerning future plans for joint schools.

4. Meetings with Officials of Church Denominations

I met Dr. Dorsey and Mrs. Lovejoy on Wednesday April 12 and will submit separate reports concerning the various schools and problems which were discussed.

Unfortunately, the Secretary of the Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church was absent from Toronto on holidays and I was unable to meet her, as I usually do.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

It will be noted from the above statistics that the enrolment at residential schools increased during the year by 32% and that the enrolment at day schools increased by 12%. This has resulted in a total increase during the one year of 2,015 (including children enrolled in combined schools).

In tables 2 and 3 are listed the Indian children enrolled in provincial and private schools. There are now 285 Indian children in elementary grades and 377 Indian children in secondary grades in such schools. Added to the totals above, this means that there are now 23,293 Indians enrolled in educational classes.

The increase in the percentage of attendance from 80.3% to 85.33% is also noteworthy. Children have been much more prompt in returning to Indian residential schools after the summer holidays. At Indian day schools, the attendance has steadily improved as a result of family allowances payments, the better salaries of teachers employed and improvements in classroom equipment and materials.

The building of new day schools and the opening of classroom blocks at residential schools has continued at a steady pace. The number of day schools increased during the year from 285 to 300 and entire classrooms were added to several schools. In all, nearly 50 more classrooms were provided in day and residential schools.

The Special Joint Committee of the Senate and the House of Commons appointed to continue and complete the examination and consideration of the Indian Act, in its Committee of Proceedings and Evidence
No. 5 covering the period Tuesday April 13, 1948, to and including Monday June 21, 1948, made the following recommendation concerning the operation of Indian schools:

"Your Committee recommends the revision of those sections of the Act which pertain to education, in order to prepare Indian children to take their place as citizens.

"Your Committee, therefore, recommends that wherever and whenever possible Indian children should be educated in association with other children."

Therefore, the Education Division has been negotiating with School Boards and Provincial Departments of Education for the training of Indian children in provincial schools. The following statement shows the enrolment of Indian children in such schools in the elementary grades:

The number of Indians receiving secondary education continues to increase at a satisfactory rate. In addition to the 268 pupils enrolled in our own schools (as shown in table 4) the following summary shows the Indian children attending provincial and private schools in the secondary grades. This brings the total of Indians attending secondary schools and universities to 661.
The standard of teachers employed in our Indian day schools continues to show improvement. The number of non-qualified or Grade I teachers decreased by 16 and the number of teachers holding First Class certificates increased by 24. This trend in the hiring of day school teachers will continue as a departmental policy and we hope for the eventual elimination of non-qualified teachers entirely from our schools. At the present time the implementation of this policy is made difficult by the serious shortage of qualified teachers across Canada.

The supply of school textbooks and materials is now much better and we are able to provide our schools with teaching aids which have been difficult to obtain during the immediate past-year years. Our teachers are advised of the availability of this equipment through the medium of our teachers' magazine, the "Indian School Bulletin".

The provision of school lunch supplies has been extended and many day schools are now serving a hot meal daily. The distribution of vitamin biscuits was again made to day schools in Northern Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and the Northwest Territories.

The enrolment at residential schools has decreased slightly but there has been an increase in the day school enrolment of 1,582. Since 1947 there has been a total increase in day school enrolment of 3,111 pupils.

In tables 2 and 3 are listed the Indian children enrolled in provincial and private schools. There are now 1,180 Indian children in elementary grades and 465 Indian pupils in secondary schools. Added to the totals above, this means that there are now 25,024 Indians enrolled in educational classes.

The increase in the percentage of attendance reflects the effect of better teachers, schools and equipment and the increasing realization of the Indians of the need for education.

The building of new day schools has continued and the effect of this programme can be seen in the increase in day school enrolment of over 3,000 pupils within the last two years. We are reducing the number of children for whom educational facilities are not provided and are building new schools in the northern sections of the provinces and in the Northwest Territories. Previously, many of these Indian children had no schools whatsoever.

Table 2 shows an increase of nearly 200 children enrolled in provincial schools. New agreements are being negotiated now to further increase the number of Indian children attending such schools.

In table 3 it will be noted that the number of Indian children receiving secondary education continues to increase at a satisfactory rate. We now have 465 children attending secondary grades in provincial and
private schools. In our own schools (as shown in table 4) we have a total of 369 children. This raises the total of Indians attending secondary schools and universities to 834 as compared with 661 pupils last year.

Teachers at Indian Day Schools

A steady improvement is shown in the qualifications and experience of teachers employed in our Indian day schools. The number of non-qualified or Grade One teachers decreased by 7 and the number of teachers holding First Class Certificates increased by 39. The raising of the standard of teaching has resulted in improved attendance and a reduction in "drop-outs". This is shown in table 4.

Vocational Education

The Supervisor of Vocational Education has reported that the Proficiency Badge system has proven quite successful. A total of 7,645 badges have now been distributed to Indian pupils for proficiency in various basic operations.

In day schools it is often difficult to encourage a programme of manual training because so many of our schools have but one teacher. In order to help these teachers and also other manual training teachers, two booklets have been prepared entitled "First Year Woodwork" and "Second Year Woodwork". A third book is in course of preparation.

In residential schools we are gradually securing the services of more and better qualified instructors. We are also beginning a programme of erecting small manual training shops at the larger schools.

Physical Education and Recreation

A new supervisor has been recently appointed and is now conducting surveys at various reserves and schools. We have purchased considerable supplies of sports equipment and have encouraged athletic activities of various kinds. Our school teams have been particularly successful in hockey and several bantam, midget and juvenile championships have been won.

A programme of adult education has been started and we intend to encourage further courses, particularly at day schools. Some home and school associations have been started and this new official will encourage the formation of others. It is felt that Indian parents must be encouraged to take an active interest in the education of their children.
Ottawa, May 25, 1950.

Memorandum:

THE DIRECTOR,

Report on School Openings, Southern Ontario.

1. Mohawk Institute:

I arrived in Brantford at noon Sunday May 14, and there met Mr. Morris and Colonel Randle. We visited a new brick four-room school being constructed at Princeton, near Brantford. This is the type of building which Colonel Randle wishes for an intermediate consolidated school at Chateaugay. I will submit a separate recommendation on this proposal.

We found things improved at the Mohawk Institute with Mrs. Zimmerman in a better state of health. I would recommend that we proceed with the principal's residence as soon as possible. We are wasting valuable space in the main building and are further jeopardizing her mental health by leaving things as they are.

The work being done on the upper dormitories is proceeding satisfactorily. The workmanship is good and I am particularly impressed with the use of Masonite panels instead of plaster. I feel that we could use this on all the lower walls in dormitories hallways, etc., in future.

We are including an amount for further work on this building in our Supplementary Estimates as we can now proceed with the many repairs required to the walls in the various rooms.
2. Diocese of Huron

Unfortunately, I was not able to see the Bishop of Huron as their Synod was in session. However, I did meet the Diocesan Commissioner and discussed various matters with him. We naturally discussed Mr. and Mrs. Zimmerman.

3. Back Settlement School

This opening was held at 10:30 a.m. on May 15th. There was a good crowd of Indians in attendance. The Provincial School Inspector, Mr. Caines, Mr. Joblin and Mr. Morris all spoke well. Pictures of the building indicate the good workmanship. This was erected by Indians under a white foreman-carpenter.

4. Osida No. 2 School

This opening took place at 2:30 on the same afternoon. There was an even larger crowd of Indians. The school was opened by Mr. H. McCubbin, M.P., Mr. W. Smith, the Provincial School Inspector for this section of the reserve,
spoke very highly of the building. Mr. Joblin, Mr. Morris and some of the Indians also spoke. This is an even better building than Back Settlement with electricity and running water. The teacher, Mrs. Johnstone, had it beautifully decorated and all the visitors were noticeably impressed. The concert put on by these children was very good.

5. Hareviantown

This opening took place at 2:30 Tuesday May 16. It was held outside and attracted a very large group of Indians. This building is undoubtedly the best of the four we opened. There was very little white supervision and the Indians really put in many extras in their work. I have already sent you a newspaper account of this opening and attach additional photographs. The children put on a very fine Chinese play. Mr. Barrett, the Provincial School Inspector and other white officials spoke well but the Indian Chief here was most outstanding. His address was exceptionally fine and sincere. Mr. Spence proved a good chairman and this opening was a great success.
6. Walpole Island

This school was built by contract and the finish is not as good as on those buildings erected by Indian labour. You will note that there is no basement, due to the low lying land surrounding the building. It is not possible to have a proper basement on Walpole Island. This opening was held indoors and the school was packed. The Provincial School Inspector, the Mayor of Wallaceburg, the Principal of Wallaceburg High School and the Indians all spoke. Mr. Stallwood proved a very capable chairman and the programme put on by the children was diversified and interesting. The Indian number shown in my photograph was particularly good. The other photograph shows the Provincial Policeman playing with the children after the opening.

I would like to recommend that the Deputy Minister be given an opportunity of looking at this report, particularly of the buildings erected by Indian labour. I feel that we are getting exceptionally good value in these buildings and that the finishing details are better than those erected by contractors.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

J. M. Game

JM/W Incl.
"COMMENTS BY TEACHER #1

Regarding changes in the curriculum in history and science:

While I think that physical education (within specified limits) and personal hygiene should be given great attention, I do not think that history and science should be touched on but lightly. I think that these subjects should be given their proper place on the Programme irrespective as to whether the pupils are going on to high school or not.

My experience in teaching those subjects has proved to me that Indian children (as well as others) show keen interest in them and I think them most useful to any child.

It seems to me that without at least a fair knowledge of history one has but a meagre idea of the political and social life of the world and its people. This I believe every child should have.

The course in science as outlined in the curriculum is, I think, not only necessary for those going on to high school since it takes in the all important and everyday knowledge which any child should have."
"I shall endeavour to make a few comments on Resolution IV.

What our children need is more and better teaching in every subject on the curriculum and there is a danger here in lowering our standards instead of raising them.

I believe the Indian children need the same things taught to them as other children in our land. We believe we have an interesting course of study in Social Studies and I have found the children enjoyed it, so why should an Indian child be deprived of going to Africa with David Livingstone; or to Mexico with Cortez; to Peru with Pizarro or down the rivers and across the mountains of Canada with the explorers? Why should they not know the facts concerning the history of their own land?

Last year I followed the course in Science outlined by you and always had their keenest attention. It was no trouble for them to learn about the planets, the sun, the moon, the cause of the seasons, how coal is formed, etc., etc. I can't see why they shouldn't learn this.

Now regarding personal hygiene and physical training, I found I could only go a certain distance in teaching personal hygiene and then they resent it. I tried to teach those topics on the health course such as foods, clothing, bacteria, means of controlling communicable disease, cleanliness, etc. The result should be the same as with white people—it should affect the way they live.

I can go to the end of my rope in teaching Personal Hygiene and Physical Training along with following the course in Social Studies and Science.

We should consider also the location. What I am saying is meant for this Reserve not one in some remote part of the north. There is a real need here for progress in education and I think the teachers should be made to feel this and try as much as possible to reach the required standards of the Department of Education of Ontario."
"I was very much interested in the resolution submitted to our recent convention by a teacher from an Indian school. After a period of eleven and one-half months in an Indian School and somewhat longer in various 'white' schools, I should like to submit the following comments:

(1) I believe we are not justified in (mentally or otherwise) segregating the Indian children or in comparing them adversely with (so-called) 'white' children. I believe their situation parallels that of most under-privileged 'whites.' It is true that social workers often find training in 'personal hygiene' advisable and necessary for under-privileged groups, but they have also found that with improved self-respect and a higher standard of living habits of personal cleanliness and physical well-being have usually improved proportionately. As some wit has tersely warned us, we should be careful not to 'put the cart before the horse.'

The English difficulty, common to all non-Anglo-Saxon children in Canada, requires that English practice be given a proportionably large place on the time-table, but much of this can also be learned incidentally through suitably chosen games and more careful supervision and help in oral and written work in the other academic subjects. With these two exceptions, I believe no distinction should be made between 'Indian' and 'white' schools as such.

(2) If any change in curriculum is advisable for Indian children who are not expected to continue their education after Grade VIII, the same should also apply to 'white' children in this category both in rural and in urban schools.

A more 'utilitarian' course, including a larger proportion of less-academic subjects such as Household Training and Manual Training certainly has proved a boon, I believe to such students who have had the opportunity for this type of training. In this way they have been able to 'make good' and in some line in which they have ability. Such results are noticeable in special schools, such as Bolton Avenue School for Girls and Edith L. Groves School (and the corresponding Boys' School) in Toronto, and should also be seen in the Indian residential schools if they were open to all who wished or needed this type of training, and not just a home. I believe the resolution might well encourage more schools of this type (for both Indian and 'white' indiscriminately) with the removal of the 'low mentality' and 'broken home' stigmas respectively.

(3) Many Indian and other rural (and urban) children who at present cannot attend High School are prevented not so much by lack of academic ability or interest as by lack of financial means to pay for board and/or transportation.

(a) The formation of High School districts should solve their transportation problems.

(b) The provision of may more adequate scholarships and grants, and also library and other bursaries, should be encouraged to aid those who require financial assistance. (From my personal observation of the operation of scholarship and bursary systems at the University of Toronto, I am convinced that the same principles could profitably and should be extended to the Secondary schools.)

With such improvements within sight, and the promised renewal of grants to Indian children continuing to High School, Indian teachers should encourage more of their children to continue their education, and therefore will need to intensify rather than minimize their teaching of some academic subjects (particularly those that present language difficulties), so that those who graduate to High School will be academically prepared to progress normally in the higher grades.

It may be that we as Public School teachers in this 'era of expansion' will need to be better informed about the present trends in Secondary School Education, including the types of courses open to students, and the background of knowledge necessary for each.

In conclusion, I should like to repeat that I heartily agree that any course of study (in elementary school especially) should admit of some adjustment (as our Ontario Programme does) to the needs of the individual pupil; but I also believe that with increased transportation facilities and financial assistance more of our pupils will be encouraged to continue their education after Grade VIII, in some line in which they are interested. Also I should like to emphasize my conviction that the same principles should apply to 'Indian' schools and 'white' schools indiscriminately."
With respect to your letter re resolution:

I have checked the course of study in Natural Science and I find that at different times I have used about 75% of the topics listed. Grades 1-2-3 get very little outside of family objects and tracing and colouring drawings of nature. Grades 4-5-6 seem to absorb about 50% of these lessons, possibly most of the work for Grades 1-2-3 responses are very poor.

I have taken lessons using magnets, bells, coffee perk--anything to arouse interest. They liked these mechanical lessons fine. They know what most tools are for and how to use them. One lad took his bicycle apart and everyone helped, this was enjoyed by all. Many parts of this course must be omitted but I think my children like and enjoy most of these lessons.

As for Social Studies, Grades 1-2-3. It is impossible and useless in my school to lessons on this subject as the children cannot understand. I use pictures of peoples of other lands. If they get anything from it, they only know. (The Indian people in my section don't bother to talk to their children about school or anything else.)

Grades 4-5-6 taken mostly together do not take to history stories and I have had no luck in teaching them. It's like pulling teeth to get answers.

The greatest drawback is the fact that the parents won't put themselves out to talk in English. There is no discussion of school work at home with the parents.

The children do not get away from home often enough to get an interest in outside affairs. One family speaks English at home and are about 75% brighter than the others but go past their simple understanding and the Indian nature shows up--result no answers.

I think that unless the Indian child comes from a home where English is spoken and they wish to continue school, this part of Social Studies should be removed.

We all take a certain amount of physical drill or games. The children would rather do this than think or write.

I think we can do much to aid in personal hygiene but the fundamentals must be taught by the parents at home. If this is not done, what chance have we?

You can see that there is no privacy or moral uplift in a one or two-roomed house where animal instincts take their course. Marriage laws do not hold out here and the Indians trade unions or just go and live with someone else.

The only remedy for Indian children of this reserve to get an education and amount to something would be to adopt them into a home at about 6 months old so that they would have no contact with home until their education was complete."

I am sending forward herewith report forms indicating the number of teachers employed at Indian day schools, their age, academic and professional qualifications, etc.

I am sending forward also Education Bulletin No. 1, 1946, secured by me from the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

I regret that the time at my disposal has not enabled me to undertake a study of this information, which has been prepared by the Chief of the Training Division. It has occurred to me, however, that in view of the shortage of teachers at present employed, lacking professional standing, plus the many who have reached an age ordinarily looked upon as too old for employment, it would be exceedingly difficult to recognize the claims of the members of either of these groups for permanent appointment in the civil service or for superannuation purposes. In addition to this, it would be exceedingly difficult in view of the present shortage of teachers prevailing throughout the country to secure teachers at this time to take their places; should these teachers be discharged from their present positions, there would be much work to be done and the prevailing shortage of teachers insure that the full shortage is likely to remain for a period of at least ten years.

I am submitting this information for study and review. In so doing, I find it exceedingly difficult to see how the adjustments we have in mind can be made in time for the opening of the regular academic year of September 1st. However, it is to me a source of great personal gratification...
to note that the matter is now receiving careful study and that certain adjustments seem satisfactory to the Government and to the teachers will be worked out in due course.

Herewith quarterly report of the Agent, Bella Coola Indian Agency, also administering the Skeena River Agency, for the period ending June 30th, 1946.

In connection with Family Allowances and their relation to education, something will have to be done to simplify this situation as far as the removal and replacement of accounts in pay is concerned. The present set up may be likened to "In Again, out again, on again, Flanagan." With infrequent mail service, monthly reports do not reach the agents sometimes for three weeks after the close of a month; and by the time a cut-off reaches the Family Allowance Branch another two or three weeks may have elapsed, by which time the child has returned to school and its attendance has improved to the point where the account is put back into pay and so the merry-go-round goes on. We have children who have been cut off and put back as many as five or six times in a school year. At Bella Coola a card index system has been installed and this will be put in at Prince Rupert this fall. I believe that a form should be devised similar in size to the M.S.S. Form 180, with carbon inserted. These could be filled out by the teachers for accounts to be put in or not put in pay. The original to be mailed in direct to the Family Allowance Regional Director, two copies to Agency and one for parents. They could be worded so that the average teacher could handle them with ease. They would do away with the monthly reports of attendance (which can be checked in registers by Agent's on patrol) and the teacher would have to deal only with cases of actual truancy of children from school who are resident in the village during the month in question. It is my opinion that if children accompany their parents to canneries or traplines where there are no school facilities, they should not be penalized for Family Allowance. It is ridiculous to expect parents to live in an Indian village without work merely to have their children attend school and to obtain Family allowance payments. The schools will have to be extended on a seasonal basis in more canneries, similar to the set-up at Port Edwards and Sunnyside canneries at Skeena Agency.

Living costs today are such that an Indian cannot afford to spend the winter in his home village unless he has access to employment at the same time.

The situation with regard to teachers in the Indian schools is still unsatisfactory. In the two Agencies administered by the writer, twenty-seven classrooms should open in September and for them fourteen teachers are now appointed.

Y. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Dear Colonel Neery,

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 15th,
1-1-1 X W T, and take this opportunity of congratulating you
on your appointment as Superintendent of Welfare and Training.
I trust that before long I may have the pleasure of making your
acquaintance and that our contacts will be as happy as those
I have enjoyed in the past with your predecessor.

I have studied the above form and think it is ad-
mirably planned for its purpose. Possibly in actual use some
amendments may appear to be desirable but at the moment I have
nothing to suggest.

May I take this opportunity however of making plain
that this Commission is concerned with residential schools only.
We have been concerned with the day school on the Sarcee Reserve
near Calgary but only because this was formerly a residential
school. I think it well to avoid confusion that we should return
the supply of forms as it will be better for the directions in
regard to their use to come from your office rather than from
ours. I enclose a list of the Bishops to whom I think a letter
with forms should be addressed.

I have noted in the evidence given before the Parli-
amentary Committee of Inquiry the assumption that too many
teachers are being appointed without the necessary qualifications.
I can assure you that as far as this Commission is concerned it
has consistently been our endeavour to secure fully certificate
teachers. I find that in the last school year only about three
of our teachers lacked teacher training certificates and in each
case there were educational or other qualifications which balanced
the lack of a formal certificate. We are finding it a little
difficult now to maintain this standard for the coming year but this is not surprising when Provincial governments are issuing many hundreds of temporary teaching permits and not a few Indian day schools have been closed for lack of teachers.

With every good wish, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

N.A. Alderwood

Dear Sir:

I have yours of the 22nd inst., enclosing forms of Application for Employment in Indian Day Schools, which same I welcome as most useful in securing necessary information regarding applicants for the position of teacher.

May I make one comment? The term "Religion" might be made more definite by the question "Religious Denomination" which I presume is the information required. The answer to the question as to religion would or should be Christian or otherwise, while what we would desire to know is what branch of the Christian religion the applicant embraces or follows. It is perhaps a small matter, but experience has taught that the more specific question is desirable, and its answer more helpful.

May I say that I have advertised for a week in the two daily newspapers of Winnipeg for teachers for Jack River and Hollow Water River Day Schools in separate advertisements, and though two weeks have passed I have not received any applications. Through this portion of Western Ontario, and throughout Manitoba, there is a definite shortage of rural teachers, and it is increasingly difficult to secure teachers for remote areas.

Our missionary at Big Trout Lake informed me a week or so ago that the Indians at that centre and also at Windigo Lake have asked him to appeal to me for teacher schools and teachers. There are also other bands, such as Cat Lake, and also Duo Lake, 175 miles north-west of Churchill where we should have schools. It is our hope that a Residential School will be provided near the Hudson Bay Railway as promised in 1939. We could fill two such schools with children who at present have no facilities for education.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

PROPOSALS FOR GRADES OF CIVIL SERVANTS TO BE EMPLOYED IN THE WELFARE AND TRAINING SERVICE OF THE INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

Teacher, Indian School

Teacher, Indian School, Grade I 1000-1120.
Teacher, Indian School, Grade II 1200-1560.
Teacher, Indian School, Grade III 1260-1980.
Teacher, Indian School, Grade IV 1500-2220.

Classification Regulations

1. Teacher, Indian School, Grade I.

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold certificates from a recognized Normal or Teachers' Training School. After 1 September, 1947, it will be the policy of the Department to employ only teachers who hold recognized teaching certificates. Any non-certificated teachers employed as of that date can be retained in the service but no further non-certificated teachers will be employed except in the event of an emergency. If this is necessary such teachers will fall into this category.

(b) Salary raises to £1060. and £1120. will be given for satisfactory service in the first three years only as shown on the salary scale.

2. Teacher, Indian School, Grade II

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a Second Class Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring High School Junior Matriculation plus teacher training at a recognized school).

(b) Salary raises for satisfactory service will be given annually for the first seven years only as shown on the salary scale.

(c) No teacher shall be eligible for the increments provided in the fourth or seventh years of service according to the scale attached hereto, unless such teacher has at some time in the preceding three year period respectively, completed one professional or academic session at a Provincial or University Summer School for teachers, or an equivalent course recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

3. Teacher, Indian School, Grade III

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a First Class Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring High School Senior Matriculation or First Year University) plus teacher training at a recognized school. Specialist teachers with First Class Certificates in Industrial Arts, Household Science, Agriculture or other specialist field will also be classified in this category.
(b) Salary raises for satisfactory services will be given annually for the first ten years; thereafter at the end of the 14th and 19th years of experience.

(c) No teacher shall be eligible for the increments provided in the 4th, 7th, 10th, 14th and 19th years of service according to the scale attached hereto, unless such teacher has at some time in the preceding three or five year period respectively, completed one professional or academic session at a Provincial or University Summer School for teachers, or an equivalent course recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

4. Teacher, Indian School, Grade IV

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a High School Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring a University degree plus teacher training). Specialist teachers with High School Certificates in Industrial Arts, Household Science, Agriculture, or other specialist field will also be classified in this category. It will be further required that 50% of such teacher's teaching time be spent in Grade IX and upwards.

(b) Same as for Teacher, Grade III.

(c) Same as for Teacher, Grade III.

TEACHER, INDIAN WELFARE

1. Teacher, Indian Welfare, Grade 1 $1200-1320.
2. Teacher, Indian Welfare, Grade 2 1380-1740.
3. Teacher, Indian Welfare, Grade 3 1500-2220.
4. Teacher, Indian Welfare, Grade 4 1740-2460.

CLASSIFICATION REGULATIONS

(a) These regulations shall be the same as for Teacher, Indian School. Normally these will be teachers of day schools situated on isolated reservations.

(b) These teachers can qualify for the salary increments requiring summer school courses by taking correspondence courses from Provincial Departments of Education, Universities or other schools recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

(c) These teachers will remain on the reservations during the usual summer holiday period. They will be given the normal Civil Service holidays totalling eighteen days throughout the school year.

(d) These teachers will, in addition to their normal teaching duties, carry out social and welfare work, assist in the administration of family allowances, the dispensing of medicines and work towards the general welfare and advancement of the Indian people as required by the Indian Affairs Branch.
(c) These teachers may be granted a leave of seven weeks once every three years to enable them to attend a course in social welfare, sociology, child psychology or allied professional field at a Canadian or American University or school recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

PRINCIPAL, INDIAN SCHOOL

1. Principal, Grade 1 $1380-2100
2. Principal, Grade 2 $1500-2220
3. Principal, Supervising, Grade 3 $1740-2460
4. Principal, Supervising, Grade 4 $1860-2580

1. Principal, Grade 1, $1380-2100.

   (c) No principal shall be eligible for the increments provided in the fourth, seventh, tenth, fourteenth and nineteenth years of service according to the scale attached hereto, unless such teacher has at some time in the preceding three or five year period respectively, completed one professional or academic session at a Provincial or University Summer School for teachers, or an equivalent course recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

2. Principal, Grade 2, $1500-2220.

GENERAL REGULATIONS:

1. For the purpose of determining the teacher's salary in the scale attached hereto, and for the purpose of determining the teacher's experience for the salary increment, the teacher's total service as at the beginning of each school year shall be taken, and such salary increment shall not be revised until the beginning of the following school year.

2. No teacher in the year 1947-48 and thereafter shall, while holding the same teaching position held in 1946-47, receive a lower salary than the total amount paid him in 1946-47.

3. Time spent by a duly certificated teacher as a teacher in the public schools in any part of the British Commonwealth, or as an Instructor in a University in any part of the British Commonwealth, shall be regarded as time spent in teaching in the schools of the Indian Affairs Branch, provided that the maximum period of such teaching service to be regarded shall not exceed five years. Such teachers must also have attended one professional or academic session at a Summer School Course recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch in order to qualify for the increments described above in the regulations for grades of teachers.

4. In schools in which English is the language of instruction, the teacher's certificate must be for the English language to be recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch for the purposes of the salary scale.

5. In schools in which French is the language of instruction, the teacher's certificate must be for the French language to be recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch for the purposes of the salary scale.

Attention is invited to a circular of the Department of Education
of Ontario which indicates how schools in Ontario may supplement the reading
material available to pupils and parents. The circular is quoted in full:

DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION, ONTARIO
PUBLIC LIBRARIES BRANCH,
Travelling Libraries Service

"The object of these travelling libraries is to supplement the
available book stock of smaller public libraries as well as to serve the
women's institutes, farmers' clubs, study clubs and schools in communities,
rural and urban, where public library service is not accessible. Requests
for special titles or special types of literature will always be filled so
far as possible; for example, agriculture, household science, travel,
biography, economics, boys' and girls' books. A case holds from forty to
fifty volumes.

Occasionally requests are made for cases entirely of fiction.
Such applications cannot be granted, since the libraries are chiefly for
educational purposes.

For practical reasons no catalogue is published. New books
are being purchased every month, worn-out volumes are being withdrawn,
and much of the collection is always in circulation throughout the
Province.

Cost -- None, except carriage charges. The borrowing community
is asked to pay the charges on arrival; the Department will pay for the
return. A case of books weighs approximately seventy-five pounds. The
case should be returned by the same mode of transportation used by the
Department.

Period of Loan -- The regular period for a loan is four months,
though cases may be returned as soon as the books are read, and another
case procured but only one case may be procured at a time.

The Department prefers to lend through an organized association
of some kind. The books must be available without charge to the entire
community and not only to the members of an association, club or church.
Arrangements must be made for a suitable custodian."

The Indian Affairs Branch has very limited funds available to
defray the cost of transportation or loss of such travelling libraries.
Several schools are already using this service and are meeting the small
expenses involved by raising funds by community efforts such as concerts,
bazaars, etc. If such community contributions are not readily available,
then application can be made through the Indian Agent for necessary funds.

Dear Mr. Hoey-

As I was not accepted for a position in one of the Indian schools for the summer, I gather that I did not have sufficient qualifications. I should very much appreciate if however, if you would keep me in mind for next summer, at which time I shall have completed my second year in college and be more qualified for such an important undertaking.

It would be of great assistance to me if you could tell me just what is needed for such a position as perhaps there is some outside work which I could do that would be of value in future work of this kind.

As the need for closer cooperation between Whites and Indians will follow as a result of the changes brought about by the revision of the Indian Act, there will be a greater need for properly trained people with a real interest. This should mean new openings and new positions not at present in existence. If there is to be properly trained staffs then it is rather necessary to know just what courses in University would be the most likely to give part of this training, and what additional training would be necessary. Also just how much experience is necessary to qualify for positions in the government at Ottawa or on the reserves.

I know that it is a pretty big question and that there are many problems to solve. I think that both Indians and Whites feel that since your coming to office there has been some definite improvement, and it is to be hoped that some day the Indians will be working side by side with the white people in the government as well as elsewhere.

Thank you very much for sending me all the information on the committee investigating the Indian Act. It has been a great help in understanding better the problems that face both the government and the Indians.

Yours very sincerely,

Dear Mrs. Hoey,

At present I am going to university, and will eventually be taking a teacher's course in the hope that I may some day be able to work on an Indian Reserve. It does seem to me however, with four free months that I should be able in some way to gain a little experience which would be of real value later.

I realize that you have summer training courses, but what I was wondering was whether there are no other opportunities as the course seems to be filled with more qualified people while it only proper.

I notice that there is often mention of shortage of clerical help in the agency keeping the agent tied down when he could be making more use of his time. Would it not be possible for students who are genuinely interested, to help out during their vacations, particularly in agencies where obtaining permanent help immediately presents some difficulties? In this way the student could gain valuable experience. He would also become familiarized with the difficulties facing...
the Department and Agent as well as gaining a knowledge of Administrative methods. He would gradually learn how the Agent solves the problem facing him, gain a knowledge of the problem as seen from the Indian's point of view as well as relieving the Agent of some of the burden of clerical work.

It would also give the Department a chance to see if the person were suited to the work and in what position eventually he might prove most useful. This would mean a potential staff in the future, and alleviate the necessity of waiting so long in order to find the right person for the job. The student could return each year for four or five years and thus would have sufficient time for the Agent to become thoroughly acquainted with the student. At the end of this time (taking for granted that the student has proved satisfactory), a full report could be sent to Ottawa.

If this plan would not seem feasible I should very much appreciate it if you could tell me if there is any kind of work, either at Ottawa or in the field (the latter preferably) which might be available within this summer or next.

I have just completed my first year of college in Social Science with first class honors. I have three years working experience in typing, bookkeeping, and general office work, as well as reception work. I have had a good deal of experience with children, having taught an incoming and nursing school.
and have been quite successful in my work with them as I am exceedingly fond of both children and adults.

I have spent a short time around Indian Reserve and have many Indian friends. I am also teaching myself Cree, and short hand, and studying the reports on the investigation of the Indian Act by the Senate and House of Commons. Trusting that I may be of some help, I remain,

Yours very sincerely,

I am an experienced teacher holding a first-class permanent certificate, B.A., B.Ed., (gold medal for general proficiency) — together with commercial specialist's certificate and special training in music, especially in piano and children's vocal work. I am interested in your advertisement which appears in the current issue of the Montreal Daily Star.

Should I find the type of position for which I am looking, it would matter little in which province the school was located. Years ago I knew in Winnipeg a very fine lady, rather elderly, who had served as nurse in the residential school at Norway House. (Please do not misunderstand and imagine that I am so stupid as to look for a post in an Indian Residential Church School in a list of day school vacancies furnished by the Department of Indian Affairs). I remember distinctly, however, the good lady explaining that the day school teacher at Norway House, who had of course engaged and paid by the Dominion Government, lived with the staff of the residential school; in fact, there was a working arrangement whereby the two co-operated so as to provide more intelligent grading, and so forth. THAT IS THE TYPE OF POSITION FOR WHICH I WISH TO APPLY.

And now a confession or two. Perhaps I could cook well enough to keep myself alive — for a while — but I would be a very short while. Next, during the war years I forsook the teaching profession, following business interests which proved somewhat more remunerative than any high school principal's post. I am well to do, but I have a tremendous fondness for children — especially underprivileged ones — and I feel that in addition to presenting intelligently the various subjects of the curriculum I might be able to spread something in the way of sunshine for the benefit of those boys and girls, whose later lives are likely to be dark enough.

I am an Ontario-born Protestant. I'm no flaming evangelist, but inspection reports have led me to believe that I am a capable teacher. As a teetotaler,

Yours Truly,

TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN:

Dear Sir:

Below is a statement setting forth: I - general information in regard to myself; II - my education; and III - positions I have held.

I. GENERAL INFORMATION

I was born on June 27, 1895 (51 years of age) in Stockholm, Sweden; came to Canada on October 22, 1927; and was made a Canadian Citizen on December 21, 1932.

My height is 5'10"; my weight is 220 pounds; I am in excellent health; physical defect; I am deaf on the left side.

I am married, Mrs. Figgis being a Canadian Citizen.

We have two children: son, age 16, and daughter, age 13 years, both born in Canada.

I speak, read and write English, Swedish and German well; I am able to teach Swedish and German at any scholastic level.

Various articles and lectures of mine have been published, and I hold a Membership Certificate from the Newspaper Institute of America, New York City, 1939.

A Senior Matriculation Chemistry of mine has also been published (James Texts, Educational Publishers, Belleville, Ontario, 1942; $3.50).

I am a member of the Agricultural Institute of Canada.

II. EDUCATION

I have a University training corresponding in the Province of Ontario, Canada, to a Bachelor of Science in Agriculture and Forestry, (Avilan's College, Lund, Sweden, 1918-20); a Master of Science in Agriculture and Forestry, (Ultuna Institute, Upsala, Sweden, 1920-22); Ph.D.-thesis in Agriculture and Forestry Economics, including Statistics, (University of Halle-Wittenberg, Germany, 1922-24); and a Bachelor of Divinity, including a training in Library Operations, in Social Science and Welfare, (University of Heidelberg, and of Muenster, Germany, 1924-27).

III. POSITIONS HELD AND FACTS NOT HERETOFORE COVERED

1. Sept. 1942 - Present: I am present engaged as a Professor of Chemistry and Mathematics, The University of New Brunswick, Fredericton, N.B., Canada, teaching Freshman courses. I lecture also in Citizenship and Social Science; and I am used frequently as a speaker at Educational gatherings. Salary: $2,400.00 per school year.

2. Feb. 1944 - Sept. 1945: I was employed as an Examiner, Trade and Finance Section, Directorate of Censorship, Department of National War Services, Dominion of Canada, Ottawa.

My work called for a wide range of languages, a knowledge of international trade and finance regulations, and experience in writing reports.

Reason for leaving: the cessation of Censorship.

3. Jan. 1943 - Feb. 1944: I was Senior Chemist, Explosives Division, Inspection Board, United Kingdom and Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, doing scientific and specialized technical work.

Reason for leaving: curtailment in production of explosives.
III. POSITIONS HELD AND FACTS NOT ALREADY COVERED (Cont.)

4. Sept. 1940 - Dec. 1942, I was in charge of the Science Department, Aubury College, Ottawa, Ontario, preparing the Senior Students in Natural Science: Biology, Chemistry and Physics, including laboratory work.

I also taught German.

Reason for leaving: decrease in number of Senior Students on account of their enlistment in the Armed Forces.

Appointed by the Department of Education, Province of Ontario, Toronto, I was Associate Examiner in Senior Matriculation Chemistry for said Province, 1942.

5. April 1937 - Sept. 1940, I was Statistical Clerk, Dominion Unemployment Relief, Department of Labour, Ottawa, my work including preparation of reports in social research, and statistics, especially on the problems of Youth.

Reason for leaving: the abolition of the Dominion Unemployment Relief Branch.

6. Oct. 1927 - March 1937, The United Church of Canada, 299 Queen Street West, Toronto, Ontario, used my linguistic ability and my knowledge of Social Science and Welfare in connection with their 'All-Nations' work among the new Canadians.

I was stationed at Toronto, Ontario, 1927-30, where I was ordained a Minister on June 9, 1929, and at Hanna, Alberta, from 1930.

Reason for leaving: my work had to be closed because funds were not available due to the 'depression'.

While I was in Toronto, Ontario, June 1929, Mr. Wm. J. Beaton, K.C., Barrister, 372 Bay Street, of said City, then Vice-Consul for Sweden, recommended me as his successor when he resigned from this position.

While I was in Hanna, Alberta, January 1933, the Department of Justice of the province of Alberta appointed me a Notary Public.

7. 1918 - 1922, During the summer months, 1918 - 1922, when the Colleges were closed, I was attached as Statistician to the Economic Research Bureau of the General Agricultural Society of Sweden, Stockholm, where I prepared reports on economic research, and statistics.

8. 1914 - 1918, During the First Great War I was attached as a Clerk to the Office of the Chief of the General Staff of the Swedish Army, Stockholm, Sweden, where I gained experience in office routine and statistics, as well as in translation and interpretation work.

Respectfully submitted,

Wilhelm Schulte Tigges

Salary Over payments.

The Chief Treasury Officer has drawn to my attention the number of salary over payments occurring in the field.

Such over payments result from failure on the part of Agents to notify head-office of a separation in time for Treasury or the Central Pay Office to stop payment or adjust salary before the cheque is mailed to the former employee.

This results in considerable time and work being expended in recovering and adjusting over payments.

It is therefore required that the following procedure be adopted and inserted in "Indian Agents Refs. and Regs." Page 19.

"55. Notification of Separation.

Agents will advise Branch Headquarters by telegram immediately it is apparent that an employee is resigning or is applying for extended leave without pay. This is necessary in order to avoid salary over payment."

I am very desirous of doing Indian work, and of gaining sociological experience in dealing with primitive peoples. For this reason I should like to apply for a position as remote as my marital status will allow me to accept.

Teachers for isolated schools.

Further material for that file to which Inspectors Barry and McKennon are also giving attention.

Closed Manitoba Schools

Eighty Manitoba schools were unable to open their doors this fall for the fall term. The reason was that no teachers were available to conduct classes. In addition, 20 teachers were still needed to fill out vacancies in secondary schools. These gaps remained to be filled in spite of the fact that 58 permits had been issued to persons not yet qualified to teach, and another 60 permits were in the process of being issued.

In all probability 700 permit teachers will preside over Manitoba's isolated classrooms before the educational system is in normal operation for the 1947-48 term.

While this situation is far from satisfactory it is an improvement on last year, when approximately 800 permits were issued. It is also an improvement on Saskatchewan where, according to reports, 300 schools failed to open because of a shortage of teachers.

Even though there is some improvement, however, it is clear that the day when Manitoba teachers can get along without the help of those willing and daring enough to teach on permits is a long way off. The provincial Normal School enrolment is substantially below what the institution can accommodate. The Normal School can provide facilities for 500—yet so far this year only 360 have registered for courses. The number of teachers needed in classrooms in the province is about 4,350.

The factors which brought the shortage of teachers about are well known. Low salaries, lack of prestige in the community, insecurity of tenure, inadequate prospects for orderly advancement and unwarranted interference with individual privacy by some school boards are responsible for the plight of Manitoba schools today.

During the last few years salaries paid teachers generally have increased. It is true that certain rural areas still offer teachers financial rewards for their efforts which can only be described as discouraging. By and large, however, the salary situation is improving.

Since progress has not been made in removing the other grievances which moved thousands of able young persons out of the profession in droves when the opportunity presented itself, the best hope of effecting a remedy lies in grievances seems to lie in wider adoption of the larger unit of school administration. Within the larger unit prospects of advancement are assured, and adequate salaries offered. There is less possibility of unwarranted interference with the private life of the teachers in the larger area. The financial strength of the large area offers more chance for security of tenure. As the result the position of the teacher in such a district carries with it a more satisfying place in the community.

It may as well be recognised once and for all that the day when the teacher was something like a family retainer who was expected to be content with small pay and a great sense of "mission" is gone. The community's contribution to education will have to be greater from now on.

When we do not supply items 4 & 5, plus light, it has been suggested that we pay the person who provides quarters for the teacher. Ration or ration allowance is something else! Both allowances affect income tax.

The problem stands out sharply where our teaching is already occupied and an added teacher has to board.

Cat Clark

I have received your letter of October 14, 1947, concerning employment as a day school teacher in the Yukon or in the Northwest Territories.

Dear Irene,

I regret the unavoidable delay in answering your letter of November 17th, which was due to my absence in the field. I have just returned from an extended trip to Chapleau, Elliot Lake and Port Arthur area, and then on my return I had to visit Bemidji for a few days before settling down at home.

My delay in replying prevents you from reaching a decision in time to resign before December 1st. I am sorry for that reason, for your School Board at Pelaguet have made too many changes in recent years to be a smooth running organization.

As far as Indian Affairs are concerned, we have very often openings for teachers, in fact I would say every year for September classes. Many of our teachers have from ten to twenty years service, while others seem to change often, particularly in recent years with the existing shortage of qualified teachers.

Our salary schedule appears to be as follows: the maximum starting salary for a qualified teacher entering the Service is $1,560.00, which salary raises annually to $3,280.00. A new teacher entering the Service, regardless of her years of experience, cannot get more than $1,560.00, so it could be that a younger teacher with perhaps less experience, but with ten years in the Indian Service, is getting $1,980.00. This was the reason for Mr. Phelan not answering your last letter. He had a feeling that with your experience, and the great demand for teachers, you could do much better than the offered $1,560.00, and that further correspondence was futile. I had a chat with him this morning, and he regrets that in the rush an explanation was not given.
I am looking forward to seeing you at Markham during the Christmas holidays, when we can have an opportunity to discuss the matter at a greater length. In the meantime, Anne joins me in sending our best regards.

Sincerely yours,

W. S. Arnall,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I should like to enquire about teaching in the Dominion Indian School System.

This June I shall graduate from Columbia University with a Bachelor of Science degree in Fine Arts Education which will culminate seven years of education in the fine arts - four in university, two in the Vancouver School of Art and one in the Victoria Normal School. I have also taught for a few years - one of these in the Northwood Indian Day School at Inklisep in British Columbia.

While I enjoyed living among the Indians and teaching at Inklisep, I could see little future in it for me, especially in the art field. At that time there seemed to be no concerted programme for arts and crafts education throughout the Indian school system, although many schools did exceptional work and individual teachers such as Anthony Walsh at Inklisep did a tremendously good job. It seemed a great pity to me that some overall attempt to keep all the schools informed on the best art and craft procedures was not established along with some agency to help teachers instigate up-to-date teaching methods to activate the great creative potential of the Indian child and to vitalize the traditional crafts of the various Indian communities.

If you will excuse my presumption, I would like to say that if such a programme has been instigated since I have taught or if there is any chance of one being included in your system I feel that my training and background would qualify me to handle a position in area supervision, as a travelling helping teacher or in curriculum planning. I would be grateful if you would write to me if you are at all interested in my proposals or if there are any positions in the Department in which you might think me interested.

Sir,-recently there spoke over this desk the University student, Pat O'Connor, who criticized the C.C.F.'s educational policy by quoting the fact that in Saskatchewan, 850 persons teaching with valid certificates held invalid certificates, and "had the schools been properly financed under the C.C.F. government, our boys and girls would be developing in conditions they should use."

Now Mr. O'Connor, no doubt, could have made Saskatchewan citizens not hold very well paying jobs, but he could easily find elsewhere in Canada to fall for his line. He would like to believe Saskatchewan is the only province with a shortage of teachers.

The figures I have as of June show that Nova Scotia, Alberta has 642 permit teachers, or ten percent, while Prince Edward Island has twelve percent. Manitoba, under a Liberal - Progressive-Conservative Coalition government, seven percent unqualified teachers. Ontario has fifteen percent, New Brunswick, Ed- ward Island has eighteen percent as compared to teachers holding on a permit.

So Mr. O'Connor's straw man cannot simply collapse and stand as the cause of the teacher shortage. If we look at the record of the Lib- erals during their heyday of 1937, there were 1,600 teachers owing $2,000,000 owing them on their salaries of salaries of $600 to $600 per year.

Is it any wonder that teachers are leaving the province? If ever the Liberals should return?

I wonder why Mr. O'Connor does not ask what the C.C.F. would do to solve this school shortage. Let us look at the record in 1944. The Liberal Government paid $2,000,000 in school grants. The C.C.F. Gov- ernment in the year ending March 31, 1948, paid $3,500,000 in school grants. And teachers' salaries are much higher than they were under the Liberal regime.

There are some who contend that the tax is cheaper than the school unit. Here are the facts: In my constituency, in the larger school unit, the tax is $21, whereas the same property in 1929 under the old system, paid $23.45 per quarter section in another school district. A neighbor of mine whose house lies in the town of Napier taxes which were $80 lower in Napier than in the present unit, in 1929 under the old system.

Where is the assessment of lands value? Is it not the case that the taxes may be biased? Isn't the average rate of taxes lower when we take into consideration the increased costs of goods, materials and the tendency for people to get under the larger school units?

If the Liberals and Progressive-Conservatives certainly have lots to kick about in the school situation. When they took the excess profits tax off the farmers, the Progressive-Conservatives wanted to continue it, but the farmers took them off. Now they are both happy with it.

The Liberals threw the coarse grasses away in order to jump in with because the rye futures were too high; over 800 pounds. The exchange boys were on the scene to rescue the government came to their rescue. The result—our hogs and herds reduced. Is it any wonder that this was the front page of our daily newspapers—"For Sale—Pigs—Cattle—Steers—Rams—Goats—Up to 200 pounds." That is the rec- ords of a Minister of Agriculture trying to save the government and the speculators at the same time.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Miss Marion Cowie has asked me to write you on her behalf in support of her application for a position as a teacher in the Government Service.

Miss Cowie has worked in the Department of Biochemistry for about two years. During most of that period she has been senior technician in charge of the analytical service rendered by this Department to the Kingston General Hospital, and as well has been responsible for the preparation of reagents, etc., for the work done in the laboratory by the medical students as part of their formal training in Biochemistry. In connection with this work she has had to do some instructing of other people, particularly in connection with chemical technique. I have had, therefore, an opportunity of observing Miss Cowie's capacity and ability from a number of viewpoints.

I am happy to be able to say that I believe that she is particularly well suited to be a teacher and executive administrator. She has a pleasant and charming personality. Being physically both large and strong, she possesses great energy and drive. She has demonstrated an ability to work with others and to have them work for her.

I am convinced that your service would have difficulty in finding many young women more suited than Miss Cowie to undertake teaching and other social service work in a pioneer community.

Yours very truly,

R. G. Sinclair  
Professor of Biochemistry

Dear Sir:

This is to acknowledge with thanks receipt of your letter of February 20th in which you inform us of the details of salary schedules for teachers of Indian day schools.

We feel that the establishment of these schedules is a step in the right direction and should mean a better type of education for the Indian children as the positions should appear more attractive to better qualified teachers.

You may be interested to know that in British Columbia the prevailing salary schedules are as follows:

Grade III teachers (according to your category—first class certificates) $1300-$2400 with annual $100 increments

Grade IV teachers (high school teachers)
$1600-$3000 with annual $100 increments

There are a few Grade I and II teachers in our public schools and the base schedules outlined above are modified slightly for these teachers but the minima of $1300 and $1600 still prevail.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) Stan Evans,
Assistant General Secretary,

I have delayed answering your letter until we were certain of what we were going to do with regard to our school at Sarnia. We had just completed a new school there last June and it was in use for the first time this winter.

Dear Doctor Bennett:

Your letter of May 12th was awaiting me when I returned from a recent inspection trip on Manitoulin Island.

I visited the Spanish School and had a chance to talk to Harry Whiskeychan. He seems to be quite happy there and his only worry is that he be given an opportunity of visiting his parents on Hudson Bay this year. I am taking this matter up with the Indian Health Service to see if this can be arranged.

I am writing to our local Agent with regard to your letter and plan about the Pickerel school. Our big problem there is that undoubtedly the Indian Affairs Committee is going to recommend that we do not in future build separate Indian schools where Provincial schools are available. This is, of course, confidential as yet but the tendency is to have the Indian children educated as much as possible along with whites with whom they are going to have to live in future years. However, each situation has to be considered as a separate problem and we will certainly do what we can at Pickerel.

We have just had our new salary schedule approved by Treasury Board. Teachers with second class certificates will have a range of from $1,440. to $1,920. Teachers with first class certificates will have a range
of from $1,500. to $2,220. If you run across any Catholic teachers who are interested in teaching Indians, either in Ontario or in the West, I would be only too glad to have you give them my address so that I can send them application forms.

We are particularly short of Catholic teachers in British Columbia and are only too glad to have teachers with certificates granted by such a fine province as Ontario.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Col. Beaudry,

Our visiting teacher Mrs. O'Grady who taught Harry Whiskeychum at the General Hospital in Toronto had a letter from him yesterday, the first she received since he went to Spanish School. He wrote and said he told her how much he enjoyed the school already. I thought you should know his reaction.

I visited the Peepesh Indian School (Lower French Reserve). Please see my report which I will submit today to the Dept. of Education Toronto. The old shack is being used for a school for more than 3 years and should be replaced. These will always be Indians familiarized and they should always have a little school of their own. Merging them with the whites in the public school will not benefit them. Hence couldn't a neat little school be built with a kitchen and sitting room be built? Plenty of unused lumber at your disposal here. Do please do what you can. Father Porcheron is doing nothing less than to save to rebuild it near the present school.

Dear Miss Comeau:

We have been transferring a number of our teachers and arranging for staffs at our Indian day schools in Ontario. We now have a vacancy which I think will interest you.

During last winter we completed a new two-room school on the St. Regis Reserve, near Cornwall. This school is completely modern in every way and attached to it is a comfortable teachers' cottage with two bedrooms, living room, kitchen and inside toilet and shower. We are installing an oil-burning range in the teachers' quarters.

The whole building is on a full cement basement and is heated with a hot air furnace. The attached picture does not do justice to the building as it was taken on a wet and cloudy day when I recently visited the school, then under construction. As I told you in my letter of May 26, your salary there would be £174.00 a teaching month. The second teacher will be Miss Francis, an Indian girl who is a graduate of the Valleyfield Normal School. She has a very pleasant personality and is a good primary teacher. The Priest is Reverend Father Jacobs, S.J., also an Iroquois Indian. He has a very fine reputation and has done a great deal for the Indians at St. Regis.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. T. L. Bonnah, Indian Superintendent, Cornwall, Ont. If there are any other details about the school which you would like to have, I would

Readers for Grade 4.

Dear Mrs. Murphy:

I have for answer your letter of July 9. At the present time we have two vacancies for Roman Catholic teachers in Ontario. There are none of which we are aware in the Maritimes.

Both the above mentioned vacancies are on Manitoulin Island. One is at a one-room school with attached teacher's quarters, at Rabbit Island, near Wikwemikong. This is in a rather isolated part of the country but the school is comfortable and clean. The attached teacher's quarters are adequate and quite well furnished. There are some thirty (30) odd children in grades one to eight.

The second position vacant is that of a senior teacher at the two-room West Bay Indian Day School. This school is near Mindanoya, on Manitoulin Island and is more accessible than the first mentioned. However, the teachers' quarters are not as comfortable nor as warm as the first mentioned school. The other teacher is a Miss Bruyere, who taught in this school last year.

The difficulty in both these instances is, of course, that we cannot pay your transportation. You are also aware of the fact that present regulations make it very difficult for us to employ anyone who has reached the age of 65. Therefore, we could offer you such a school for the 1948-49

Dear Mrs. Blackburn:

I have for answer your letter of November 3, which arrived when I was absent from the office. You will recall that we discussed the school at Chenaal, near Cornwall, when you visited here. Unfortunately, we can no longer offer you this position as the Sisters of Saint Ann have agreed to take over the teaching duties at this school effective 1 September, 1949.

We have also interested a married teacher in the Lakesview Indian Day School, on Manitoulin Island.

However, we are completing other schools at which we will require Catholic teachers, especially in the Northwest Territories. The main point to settle is when you would be free to take over a school with your husband as the second teacher.

With regard to the point raised concerning an appointment as an Indian Agent, please be advised that all such positions are advertised for and filled in the usual way by the Civil Service Commission.

I will expect to hear further from you in the near future.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard P. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

I have been employed for a number of years in the Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology, in Toronto, where I am at present Deputy Keeper of the Ethnological Collections. My duties here have included field trips to the Blackfeet of Alberta, and various archaeological expeditions in Ontario, as well as the care of the ethnological and archaeological collections in the Museum. Dear Doctor Moore:

Once a year it is good business to take stock of one's affairs. I have come to the conclusion that I might cease to be employed with the Indian Health Service for the following reasons:

1. No permanency of employment has been established for my position. This matter was discussed in a letter to you more than a year ago. Since then I have completed a competition application under Engineer Grade II advertisement. That was about ten months ago and I have not yet been advised of the results. Recently I have discussed this same subject with you and have been awaiting further information.

2. This position offers a very poor salary for the responsibilities involved. A competitive position in Civil Service as chief engineer for Penitentiaries offered $6000 salary in a competition advertised last year. I referred this advertisement to Doctor Procter when discussing permanency and salary last May. Large civilian companies offer experienced superintendents higher salaries than I am paid plus a bonus from the company's profits. There is no incentive to carry on at the present salary.

3. The present occupation is such that it is impossible to establish a home. It is equally unsatisfactory to supervise the scope of this work except from a central office.

4. Further, it is impossible to supervise this work from headquarters office without competent and trustworthy representatives in the field who know the details of construction and maintenance.

In view of the above matters I may consider terminating my employment in this Service at the end of this fiscal year, unless a satisfactory adjustment of these conditions have been made. In the meantime I consider myself free to make enquiries about other employment in or out of Government Departments.

Yours respectfully,

The Director, Indian Health Services,
Ottawa, Ontario.

It is interesting and well written, but it deals mainly with the personalities of the Indians met by Mrs. Thornton in her travels as an artist among them. While these verbal descriptions of the Indians and their surroundings are informative and accurate, I doubt the value of the manuscript as a textbook or even as a reference book in our schools.

The vocabulary is such that I doubt if it would hold the interest of any but Indian boys and girls in the senior grades. Therefore, I feel that we could only recommend the purchase of about 250 copies for use as library books. This number, of course, would depend entirely on the price which Dent's set for the published text.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

The Indian School Administration is in need of information concerning the person named above who has applied for a position in one of our Indian Residential Schools. It has been suggested that you could help us in this connection and we would be greatly obliged if you would answer the questions on the attached form. In view of the urgency of the need, your early reply will be appreciated.

The success of our work depends on the quality of the workers we employ and it is essential, therefore, that we make as careful investigation as possible of every applicant before appointment. The work in our schools is of an unusual nature, calling for a high degree of character and capacity. Frequently it is necessary to live in an isolated community and always there is the problem of maintaining harmonious relationships with a small group of fellow-workers. The ability to control children, ranging in age from five to sixteen, with strength but unfailing patience and kindness is absolutely necessary.

We trust, therefore, that you will be as discriminating as possible in the applicant's own interests. Relatively few people are really suited for this class of work and we have had many failures. That you say will, of course, be treated with utmost confidence and in no circumstances made known to the applicant.

Thanking you for this valuable assistance, I remain,
