ADMISSION TO NORMAL SCHOOLS IN SEPTEMBER, 1949.

The Minister of Education announces that because of the scarcity of qualified teachers in the public and separate schools, the provisions of Circular 23 N.S., printed in August, 1946, have been amended as follows:

ADMISSION TO NORMAL SCHOOLS IN SEPTEMBER, 1949.

An applicant who holds standing in five Upper School (Grade XIII) papers, one of which shall be English Literature or English Composition, (in case of the University of Ottawa Normal School, one shall be either English Literature or English Composition and a second shall be either French Literature or French Composition) will be admitted to the course leading to an Interim First Class certificate.

Application forms for admission may be obtained from the Deputy Minister, Department of Education, Parliament Buildings, Toronto, after August 1st, 1949.

NOTE (1) After Jan. 1st, 1949, the holder of an Interim First Class certificate may substitute standing in three Upper School (Grade XIII) papers in excess of the five Upper School papers required for entrance to Normal School for one Departmental summer course specified in clause 2 (b) (iii) of Section 3 of Circular 72, or may substitute an excess of six papers for two Departmental summer courses.

NOTE (2) Before final admission to the Normal School session, each applicant is required to pass a physical examination conducted by a medical examiner appointed by the Minister of Education. The medical examination for which a fee of $2.00 will be paid by the applicant, will be given at the Normal School on the opening days of the session.

Dear Sir:

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Before me is your letter of June 14, 1948. But it really seems advisable this year to make a move, in spite of my happy and comfortable location.

I will not be free until end of July—my application form, menus certificate, etc., because on "that day and age" we did not have numbers only received slips of paper and there was no number on it that I remember. At the present it is tucked away in my belongings in London.

I do not feel like doing pioneer work in some place out reach and hope there will be electric lights. I fear my eyes would not take lamp light and I would prefer Ontario if I go into day schools again. Of course, I fully realize the qualified teachers deserve and will receive first chance but if I am needed I appear to be available unless something unforeseen turns up that I am not aware of at the moment.

There is no other position I could take in your branch available, other than serving the Indians.
people and helping them is my chief concern. I've been in the work so long now (1942) that I hesitate to turn back at the last moment. However, if there is anything at the moment, I could stand a holiday for a few months.

Mr. Clark was here on a flying visit last week but it was my half-day and I missed him.

Trust you and your family are all well. Did you remember Will Ricol that worked in Gordon's store in Parkhill? He died the first week May after an operation for cancer of the liver. He was buried in Forest. His sister, Anna, who taught for years, before her marriage, in Parkhill Public School died in January so that closed the chapter on that family's book as neither of them had any family.

With kind personal regards,

Sincerely yours,

Mary B. Ross.
(Mrs. R. J. Ross)

We received your letter of May 30th enclosing your application for appointment as teacher at an Indian day school. We will have a vacancy starting September 1st at the Kettlepoint School. I am glad to state that I am familiar with Miss Margaret McNulty's work as teacher at Golden Lake between the years 1942-45, and that I consider her one of the best teachers in the province. I had occasion to examine her class, and I found them to be particularly well instructed, and at the same time remarkably mannerly and well-behaved.

I may mention also that she carried on a great deal of effective social work during these years among the parents and older brothers and sisters of the pupils. Dear Sir,

Subsequently to applying to (W.) Greening of our letter to obtain a position as a teacher, I have been referred to you.

My position is I have not heard from Normal School. I emigrated from England in March 15th this year. I approached the Department of Education in Toronto about vacancies in teaching, and they advised me that vacancies would not be filled till the end of June. Mr. Dutton said to apply to Mr. W.J. Greening then.

In the interim I took a position as operating room orderly at the Wellesley Hospital, Toronto.

In England before I taught under license privately usually children who were too few from the elementary school or neglected children who needed it for Matriculation.
In the war I was called to the army immediately being enlisted in 1940 and serving in the European theatre of war. After the war private teaching in England was reorganized under the raising of the school age act and I took a position over an accounts department in a firm of wholesale food distributors. During this break in routine gave me a wider experience and background from which to teach than a teacher in the narrow sense.

In certificates I have School certificate in English, French Latin, Greek Mathematics (Arithmetic, Algebra, Geometry), Chemistry; also Matriculation in English, French, Latin, Greek, Mathematics, History, and Chemistry; Intermediate B.A. (at Manchester University), 2nd year examination) in History, English, Latin, and Greek.

Of the other members of my family my four sisters are trained certified teachers in England. My mother too was a teacher in secondary schools before marriage. So I am in the teaching tradition and environment, and in line to come by any degree or advancement of methods. I like social work and am fond of teaching, and all children.
Much of the above mentioned it is not very convenient to forward to you at this point. My army character I do not think strictly relevant. I am enclosing a copy of my testimonial from the firm I worked for last in England. Being a man I should prefer to teach seniors.

My hobbies are cycling and hiking with the Canadian Youth Hostel Association and when in Britain the British organization (youth hostel association) of which I was an active member. I could arrange for an interview preferably weekend or public holiday though this might not suit you.

I am single.

I am thirty-eight years of age.

I enclose stamped addressed envelope for return of a reply.

Yours faithfully,

Thomas Martin McKee

Unfortunately, we can only place you as a Grade I welfare teacher because you have no qualifications nor experience in teaching. ON CHANGING A NAME

Editor, The Post-Record Star:

Referring to your change the name of the Church of England the author is not an authority of changing names generally church names. However, of the name "Church of England" is as we believe universal, it may be hoped to have it changed, and not make the change abroad. It may appear odd to some and a slight to others.

The Church of England in Canada would appear all right but the Church of England may be as also the Episcopal Church of Canada.

Another change of names that may also be of interest to us is the name "Indians." Our Indians have been going under an erroneous name for nearly 400 years and it is becoming more confusing as we are having many India Indians, B West Indians, etc., besides our so-called Indians encroaching on our American continent.

In the year 498, Admiral Shinn called them Futange, in 534 St. Brendan likely had another name for them in the year 1000 the Norwegians named "Skraelings" (little people with broad faces). Our Eskimos who were called that name but were driven farther north by the crowds of natives from the east. The Eskimos have found the north more suitable as they have not changed since.

After Columbus the natives got another name "Indians." In 1492 Columbus landed on San Labrador, Glace Bay, N.S.

At present I am living on a clear-title bush farm near by this small new place (unincorporated), working on the Northern Alberta Railroad (35 miles from Grande Prairie). We have a new school under construction to serve a mixed population of Anglo-Saxon and New Canadian citizen.

While employed as a fireman-janitor at Whitehorse, N.T., for the Canadian Pacific Airlines in 1945-6-7 and for the General Hospital there in 1948, I had occasion to meet some of our Indian people. I observed the phenomenal work of Reverend Mr. Lee and his school which I assume is under your control though not intimately acquainted. I have met Mr. Lee and also Mr. Chaffell, the rector of the Anglican Old Church. Both these gentlemen would vouch that I am a reliable character.
For almost a full year I have been resident here at my back door home or abode. This spring and summer am assistant clerk for my nearest general merchant (a widower) ten years my senior.

As an immediate reference possibly known to you, inquire of Mr. Solon Lee, M.P., Ottawa, Social Credit Dominion Representative for Grande Prairie... at least he could vouch that I'm not a recluse.

A lifetime lameness in left foot has not improved at 65 years but I retain fair general health including alert hearing and eyesight using glasses for reading fine print and for distance, am 6'1" weight 175 lbs.

Perhaps this review gives you an introduction. In 1944-5 I personally called on the Bishop of Qu'Appelle in Regina and his colleagues volunteering to go to Furnichy but before we could get through to Rev. Gordon on storm damaged telephone a lady teacher had been chosen.
Now, sir, you have somewhat of a sketch of my career and you may know that I'm quite aware there are not all ex-teachers can make comeback. Plenty of them have no ambition or courage to attempt it. That particular opening had special attractions of importance. Lodging and food provided and no janitorial duties of consequence, permitting me more time for home preparation and study curriculum covering about Grade 3 to 5.

Kindly write me your opinion and pleasure of requirements.

Yours obediently,

H.D. McCut,
Woking, Alberta.

Savoyfield,
Halifax, N.S.

I am a veteran of the Army, age 29, single, in good health, height 5'10" and weight 200 lbs. I have my Senior Matriculation Standing, and would be anxious to continue my studies while teaching. I would be willing to start at a minimum wage until I proved my ability as a teacher.
For two years now, I have directed these camps for the Department of Agriculture. The majority of our campers are students between the ages of 16 and 21, but I can handle younger students just as well if not better.

I am quite versatile in sports, and have specialized in children's games, and story telling besides hiking and camping etcetera.

In any event I am quite anxious to hear from you as I feel sure that my vocation is in teaching. Possibly you could give me some advice as to where my services could be used if not with your Branch.

Dear Mr. Neary,

There are two vacancies in Day Schools at present in my mission area. I have brought this problem to the attention of Mr. Arneil, the Commissioner, Fr' O'Grady, and the other day, to the attention of Rev. Father Bird, our Provincial. He told me to write to you. He said that you had a very nice ad in the "Ensign", and I thought, perhaps, that you might steer some of these answers out to B.C.—If there are no further applications on hand would you please consider advertising again in the "Ensign" and this time make a special appeal for teachers willing to teach in Catholic Indian Day Schools in British Columbia. Mention could be made of the wide varieties of climates to consider in the different areas where these Schools are located; (a very alluring consideration—if they only knew B.C.)

The two Schools in my area (all coastal missions 150 miles up from Vancouver) are Churchouse and Sliammon. Both these Schools have a teacherage and there should be a man and his wife at each place.

Churchouse is 150 miles up from Vancouver—the P.O. is Stuart Island, B.C. located at the entrance of Bute Inlet. There are 35 or 40 children to go to School there. This reserve is not in good conditions and the School needs a good teacher and social worker to keep it coming along with present social conditions. It's the tougher spot of the two missions.

Sliammon is 3 miles from Powell River, the paper-mill town, 80 miles from Vancouver. There are 25 or 30 pupils of School age there. The teacher's house is about 10 min. walk from the School. There should be a man and his wife here. A good social worker, both for practical nursing and encouraging the Indians in a better mode of life is necessary in both places.

Hoping you can do something to fill our needs and that of the Department's in B.C., I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY DIRECTOR

Mr. Fred Monaghan
222 McCarthy Ave., Regina, Sask.

I have Mr. Bethune's memorandum of August 26 concerning the above teacher. Mr. Monaghan formerly taught at the Skawah Indian Day School near Chilliwack, B.C. for the two academic years 1947-48 and 1948-49. Inspector Davey's reports on his work were never particularly satisfactory. His report of January 14, 1948, read in part as follows:

"There was little evidence of any attempt on the part of Mr. Monaghan to organize his work or to do any lesson preparation. No time-table had been prepared, and the exercise books showed little attempt on his part to give adequate supervision. His work in general gave a very definite impression of lack of effort. His lessons showed evidence of training and experience, but this by no means takes the place of adequate preparation."

We have been in correspondence with Mr. Ostrander concerning Mr. Monaghan, and I have a letter of August 18, 1949, from him reading as follows:

"(1) Re Mr. F.G. Monaghan, 22 McCarthy Apartments, Regina - I know this gentleman quite well, and I know that he is interested in getting a position, but I do not feel that he is at all suitable for the Piapot Indian Day School. He was considered, last year, for one of the day schools..."
at the Assiniboine Reserve, when the teacher situation was much worse than it is now. Eventually, I decided to not recommend him when I found that he is quite elderly, that he is married, that his wife insists on living in Regina, and that he intended to travel back and forth between the Assiniboine Reserve and Regina, weekends, and expected to have transportation to and from the train. He informed me that he is a retired teacher on Provincial Teacher's Pension, and I do not think we should take on "has been" teachers if we can avoid it."

In view of the information contained in these two reports, it is not our intention to employ Mr. Monaghan unless the teacher situation is such that we cannot obtain the services of more competent teachers.

Director,

"The two schools in my area (all coastal missions 150 miles up from Vancouver) are Churchouse and Slilmon. Both these schools have a teacherage and there should be man and his wife at each place.

Churchouse is 150 miles up from Vancouver -- the P.C. is Heart Island, B.C., located at the entrance of Bute Inlet. There are 25 or 30 children to go to school there. This reserve is not in good conditions and the school needs a good teacher and social worker to keep it coming along with present social conditions. It's the tougher spot of the two missions.

Slilmon is 3 miles from Powell River, the paper-mill town, 80 miles from Vancouver. There are 25 or 30 pupils of school age there. The teacher's house is about 10 min. walk from the school. There should be a man and his wife here. A good social worker, both for practical nursing and encouraging the Indians in a better mode of life is necessary in both places."

(Sgd.) Rev. F.J. Campbell, O.M.I.

Dear Miss Carisse:

I have had the Education Officials of the Indian Affairs Branch check the circumstances concerned in the resignation of Miss Margaret MacNulty as mentioned in your letter of August 25.

Miss MacNulty has had some seventeen years of experience in our Indian Day Schools. In September 1948, she was assigned as teacher to the Cornwall Island East Indian Day School near Cornwall, Ontario. On October 13, 1948, she wrote advising that she would not be able to resume her duties at Cornwall Island East after we had granted her a week's sick leave. She advised that her doctor was not sure when her allergic condition would clear up and possibly would recur due to the climate on Cornwall Island. Miss MacNulty suffers from hay fever, and the school is in a pollen area. Please find attached a copy of a letter sent by the Superintendent of Education to her at that time. On December 6 she wrote in concerning her Retirement Fund, and she was offered a position in the Fort Frances Agency or another school in the Fort Arthur Agency. Both of these positions she declined to accept because of illness in her family.

The Superintendent of Education has gone to considerable difficulty in placing Miss MacNulty in an Ontario school this year. She did not wish to accept a school too far from her home in Kenora. It has been difficult to locate a suitable school because our teachers are no longer leaving our services but due to higher salaries, superannuation and improved conditions, are remaining in our service.
However, Miss MacIntyre has been placed as the second teacher at the Sagamook Indian Day School near Neeey, Ontario. The Superintendent of Education has discussed this appointment with her by telephone. We feel confident she will be satisfied especially when the new school, now under construction, is completed.

Yours sincerely,

W.B. Bethune,
Acting Secretary.

Dear Mr. Knox,

Thank you very much for replying to my letter. I was very sorry not to be able to accept the position, but other arrangements had developed satisfactorily.

I hope I did not inconvenience you too much and that you were successful in obtaining a teacher for the vacancy.

Margaret Killoran.

Dear Miss Follett:

Mountbatten Indian Day School

I hope that my letter of September 20 has reached you as I am anxious to receive your application form.

I have just returned from an inspection trip in Northern Ontario where I have been advised of a vacancy in a school now under construction. This is the Mountbatten Indian Day School situated on the C.P. railway near Chapleau, Ontario. The name of the railway station at which the school is located is Tophet. However, there is only a section house at this point and shopping would all have to be done in Chapleau although there are two small stores, one at Nemegos and the other at Kormack. There is daily train service either East or West on trains No. 1 and 2.

You will be quite isolated at this school and I would strongly recommend that your father live with you. There will be an attached teacherage and a full basement is provided with a furnace to heat both the classroom and the teacherage.

We do not wish to employ a teacher who has not had previous experience with Indians. This band of Indians has never had any educational opportunities before and new houses are being built for them and a school erected so that a beginning can be made to improve their general welfare.
This school presents a real challenge to a teacher who is not afraid of isolation and hardship. If you are interested in this position would you please write by air mail at once to Mr. J.L. Whitney, Indian Superintendent, Chapleau, Ontario.

He will be able to provide you with other details. If you would prefer a position less isolated, then advise me accordingly.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

Recently I was informed of the great expansion programme of education in your Branch, and would appreciate any information about same.

Since 1933 I have been engaged in teaching and have had a varied experience in that field.

I have a Permanent First Class Teaching Certificate to which was added a B.A. and a B.Ed. by extra mural study in University of Toronto. Until 1941 I taught in the Public School Staff of York Township, on the outskirts of Toronto.

On the advice of Dr. W. J. Dunlop, Director of Extension at the U.F.T., I accepted a position as Educational Counsellor with the Canadian Legion Educational Service, in the
autumn of 1941. In this work I advised service personnel on courses as well as instructing classes ranging from adult illiteracy to advanced high school work.

In the following year Dr. Dunlop asked me to be his Executive Assistant at the University. I acted in this capacity until the fall of 1943 when I finally managed to enlist in the R.C.A.F. as an Education Officer. At my discharge in 1946 I was the Command Education Officer for the entire Eastern Air Command area.

In September of '46, largely due to the recommendation of Dr. Althaus of the Ontario Department of Education, I was engaged as instructor of Junior Native Baths in the Rehab. School in Toronto under Col. Wood. The academic section of this school closed in the following spring and I turned once more into the provincial system. The housing condition was such that I was forced to take schools in outlying communities. At present I am
Principal of the 4-roomed school in this town.

I am 37 years of age, am married and have three small children.

Since my discharge, the security and opportunity for advancement which I thought would be mine have so far eluded me.

I feel that I definitely have something to offer and perhaps this outline of my experience may suggest to you, some niche in your organization.

Thanking you for any consideration you may give,

I remain,

Faithfully yours,
Joe Marshall.

Travel Expense Claims

The office of the Auditor General has brought to my attention several recent examples of where officials of Indian Affairs have not conformed with Travel Regulations in the submission of expense claims.

In respect thereto the following is forwarded for your guidance:

**Meals**

(i) The actual cost of meals must be given, not the average cost.

(ii) When registered at a hotel meals should be charged to the officials account and not paid separately.

(iii) In those Provinces where a meal tax is in effect the tax will be included in the cost of the meal. For example where the Provincial tax is 5 per cent a $1.25 dinner would appear as $1.31 in the claim. Deviation from the odd cent figure at once indicates to the Auditor General that the claim is not accurate.

(iv) Gratuities are not to be included with, and shown as, a part of the cost of the meal but must be entered separately under the heading "Gratuities".

(v) When field officials stay at a private house and receive meals at the same house the receipt for charges will show the cost of meals as well as the amount paid for the room.

**Rooms**

On occasion, wives of officials travelling on public business accompany their husbands. In such cases the official must claim only for the single-room rate at the hotel utilized and not at the rate of a single person occupying a double-room in the same hotel.

I would enjoin the co-operation of all concerned to ensure that Travel Regulations, in the matter of claims, be more carefully adhered to in the future thereby ensuring less likelihood of embarrassment to those participating.
Miss Phyllis Deyell,
OKOTOKS, Alberta.

He's Back to Stay

TORONTO, Jan. 13.—(CP)—A man who, two years ago, went home to England to die, has returned to Canada to stay.

Gordon Langley Hall, 24, English teacher on the Gull Bay Indian reservation, about 200 miles north of Toronto, was told two years ago he had only six months to live, following severe injuries suffered in a plane crash.

He returned to Canada recently from his home town of Hallam, in Sussex, England, and Thursday he was hearty and well in Toronto.

"I would much rather teach in Canada", he said, "and as for going home... that's out. I'm staying."

While in England "waiting to die" he exhibited in different parts of England examples of Indian children done by Northern Ontario Indians.

"They serve to dispel that fantastic story about savage Indians and the wild west some English people still wonder about", he said.

Dear Sir:

Canon Hines mentioned to me last fall when he returned from the East that the Indian School Administration was finding difficulty in finding ordained men to place as Principals of some of their schools.

He suggested that my long experience here might qualify me for one of these positions, especially such a school as the Gordon's at Punnichy, Sask., which serves a farming community, and which we believe Mr. Mayo is leaving at midsummer.

I have made a formal application to Canon Cook for one of the open positions, but as they are positions of considerable trust and important to your department as well as his, I would like to assure you that should I be accepted as a Principal, I would give my best in faithful and
efficient service. During the eighteen years I have served here as Headman and Farm Manager and Instructor I have been in close touch with all departments of the school's work and have watched with interest the effect of its influence on the Indians of this locality. I have a sincere liking for these people and feel they are worthy of further help in solving their great problems of health and living standards.

I feel I have a good working knowledge of the organization in the school here which I could apply elsewhere to advantage because I have watched its growth over so long a period. I am well aware of the increasing educational opportunities both practical and academic which the Indian Department is offering the pupils in these schools and I should study to prepare a well balanced program for any school I might have in charge.

I have enjoyed the years I have spent here and I should be glad to use the knowledge and experience I have gained in a wider field if the administration should entrust me with one.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Dr. Falconer,

I would like to make application to your department for the nursing position in Coppermine. When Dr. Harvey was in Tuk, he told me that Coppermine station might be vacant this summer and since I want to work among the Eskimos (in a station) he suggested that I write to you.

In the fall of 1947 I made application to Dr. Moore for the nursing station at Norman but by the time the delayed reply came I was employed by Dr. G. D. O'Brien as his office nurse and secretary. Last March I came here as an emergency nurse and was in complete charge till November when another Sister came back. Since then I have one floor and the laboratory and x-ray departments.

I returned from Tuk emergency station February 23rd. The people asked me to stay with them till after breakup if not longer but I couldn't as Miss Robinson has the authority to dispense the drugs. I did feel very badly leaving them after taking only a few days to gain their confidence. Miss Robinson would like a nurse theretoo because I think she feels that the patients go to Father Franche to have the drugs she gives them checked and they do too. I guess because he has been with them for so long.

I don't know whom to discuss the following with so am choosing you. I met you and talked with you for only a few minutes but feel that you will tell me outright your opinions. I understand Miss Robinson is leaving and I was wondering, since it is a Government school, if I might teach the grades as well as doing the nursing. I am not a teacher but feel that I could do it well with the correspondence course and applying it to the Eskimo children. If you think this suggestion advisable to whom should I write. The people are really wonderful and I would stay for a three straight year period.

Would you please help me to get nursing among the Eskimos on the coast. I have tried to gain all the experience I could to apply it to a place such as Tuk or Coppermine. I love the rough outdoor life with them, and making slow progress at learning their language. My qualifications are as follows:-

Age: 29
Rel: R.C.

Prelim. Education: Jr. matriculation at Cannington continuation school, Cannington, Ontario.

1939: I entered the Oshawa General Hospital School for nurses and graduated in February 1942.

My experience since graduating is as follows:

Mar'42 - June '42 Assist charge nurse in Paediatric, O.G.H.
June'42-Dec. '42 - Assist night supervisor in C.R. and case room -O.G.H.
Jan'43 - June '43 - Private duty nursing.
June '43 - Sept'44 - General duty at I.N.C.O., Copper Cliff, Ont.
Sept'44 - Sept'46 - Operating room and emergency depts in Oshawa General Hospital.
Oct'46 - Oct'47 - General duty in Battle River Mission Hosp. in Manning, Alberta.
Nov'47 - Dec'48 - Secretary and office nurse for G.D.O'Brien, M.D., Grande Prairie, Alberta.
Dec.'48 - Feb.'49 - Emergency nurse in Rimbey, Alta.
March '49 - came here to the R.C. Hospital as emergency nurse.

Please advise as soon as possible if I may plan on Coppermine or write about Tuk.

Dear Sirs,

A friend of mine, Harold Speers of Campbellville was telling me that he is going to spend the summer teaching at Mississauga on James Bay, relieving the teacher there who had not had a holiday for three years. Are any other positions of this type available? I have experience in the north and liked it extremely well.

I am twenty-five years of age, physically over six feet tall, a Public School teacher of more than three years of experience. I first taught at Mississauga, then at White River, and the past two years at Campbellville, Ontario. At Mississauga the school was half of Indian origin and we got along splendidly. While there I lived in the teacherage and did all my own providing so I understand the problems and more than that enjoyed the experience. Besides teaching, I have taken a business course, can type, am a Sunday School Teacher in our own Presbyterian church, and have lived most of my life on the farm, therefore have a great deal of experience in the more practical things of life.

I was thinking of taking a carpentering position, or one as camp counsellor, but if I can be of any help in this capacity I would much prefer it. In the fall I am going into Toronto University, so I need not return till the middle of September.

Dear Mr. Neary:

I have written you today, officially, reporting on a number of Indian day school teachers, but, in that letter, mentioned the case of Mrs. B.G. Eugenie Thomas, and Department letter dated March 17th, 1950, File 1-1-1X (E), who apparently has applied for a teaching position.

I do not know the circumstances of her application having been received, or by whom she was originally recommended, but I wrote to Indian Superintendent McLeod to ask him to interview her, and, if possible, arrange for me to have an interview with her if he considered it worthwhile. Enclosed is a copy of his reply, which is confidential, and which I know you will treat as such. Apparently the lady, in her old age, has decided that God has called her to overhaul the Indian educational system. We have a number of old ladies in our service who have had a similar call, and, believe me, they are a headache!

Mr. McLeod has reached the state of mind that he is beginning to have an obsession against aged teachers, and, to him, the application of Mrs. Thomas is just one more. I would ask that you please do everything you can to persuade Mrs. Thomas to continue in her present work of teaching white children. As she says she is strong, healthy, and a "bear cat" to work I am sure she can do a lot of good amongst the white children.

Yours very truly,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,

I have your letter dated March 24th regarding enquiry from Mrs. Barbara Gray Eugene Thomas, Principal, Island Lake School, at Davis, Saskatchewan.

On my next visit through Davis I will call on Mrs. Thomas, however, I have met this woman previously and from my observations I do not recommend that her application receive consideration.

We have Miss Moore and any additions to our staff of women, aged and with views along same lines as Miss Moore, are sufficient. We will find Mrs. Thomas is a politician and consequently will insist upon conducting an Indian day school along political lines in opposition to present Federal Political Party. While this normally would not prevent her from conducting an Indian day school, the fact remains that all her complaints, etc. would be based on political views and in addition she would prove to be another helpless aged woman in charge of an Indian day school, and dependent upon myself and Assistant for janitor services. A further report will be submitted following an interview with Mrs. Thomas at that time I will endeavour to point out to her the disadvantages of a woman of her age entering Indian work.

We have received notification of another vacancy which might interest you. This is at the Aroland Indian Day School situated on the main C.N.R. line about 12 miles from Nakina, Ontario. It is located in a former Hudson's Bay post with the classroom downstairs and the teacherage upstairs. It is a sound and comfortable building and is isolated in that there are no roads nearby. Transportation is by rail. Nakina is a C.N.R. divisional point and food supplies are transported to the school by way freight. There is no electricity. I can give you other details of this position if you are at all interested. We would classify you as a Grade III teacher at a starting salary of $2,280.00 an academic year.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
June 23, 1950.

Mrs. Kathleen Close,
282 Jarvis St.,
Oshawa, Ontario.

Dear Mrs. Close:

I have answered your letter of June 21, 1950, and regret that we have few vacancies left other than in one-room schools in the northern parts of the Prairie Provinces.

I am sending you one of our standard application forms in the event that a vacancy might occur during the academic year in a larger school. At present, we do not have any such vacancies.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Beary,
Superintendent of Education.
